B0000VCZK2|5.0|'Alien' while technically science fiction is also one of the greatest horror/suspense movies ever made. Ridley Scott is now one of the most well known and successful directors in Hollywood, but I don't think anything he's made in the last ten years is a patch on this perfect film, which is a near masterpiece in my opinion. In fact, on reflection there are only three Scott movies I genuinely like, those being his first three. The last of these 'Blade Runner' was released twenty years ago now, so to me Scott is long past his use by date. Whatever, 'Alien' itself is a brilliant piece of work, and is almost flawless. Scott's direction is superb and everything else about it is outstanding - a strong script from Dan O'Bannon et al, an evocative score from Jerry Goldsmith, brilliant design and special effects, including the amazing contributions from H.R.Giger, all add up to an amazing movie experience. I also really liked how the cast were character actors and not \\"stars\\" so there was plenty of suspense generated as to who will live and who will die. This is something very few subsequent movies have done, 'Pitch Black' being one of the exceptions. Sigourney Weaver may be an icon as Ripley now, but when the movie was first released she was virtually unknown, having had a small cameo in Woody Allen's 'Annie Hall' and not much else. The rest of the cast are equally as good. I especially enjoyed Yaphet Kotto ('Blue Collar') and the legendary Harry Dean Stanton ('Wise Blood') as the wise cracking \\"below deck\\" crew. Many people seem to prefer James Cameron's sequel 'Aliens' over this, but as I much prefer horror and suspense movies to action ones I think this is definitely the better movie, and still the strongest and most effective in the series. 'Alien' is a horror classic and an absolutely unforgettable movie that I can't recommend highly enough. If you haven't seen it before watch it immediately!<br /><br />I would argue that ALIENS far surpasses its celebrated predecessor in almost every aspect. Obviously the sheer spectacle of what is basically a Vietnam war movie in space is particularly awe-inspiring - the impressive sets, the many excitingly-staged combat sequences, the aliens themselves (interestingly enough, although through fast cutting and appropriate camera placement it seems as though there are hundreds of aliens being blasted to kingdom come - or else picking off the gung-ho marines one by one - in reality no more than 6 aliens are ever seen in any one shot). But the human drama element of this sequel is also greatly heightened, primarily by the introduction of \\"Newt\\" (wonderful little Carrie Henn, in her only film role), who turns out to be the sole survivor of recent events on LV-426, becoming a kind-of surrogate daughter to Ripley, which leads to several touching moments and gives the story a surprisingly effective emotional core in the midst of all the otherwise pre-eminent carnage.<br /><br />The one thing that all fans of the Alien series notice about this movie is the glaring flaw at the very beginning of the film. The egg...how did it get on the Sulaco? An easy answer is the queen, but most people consider that impossible and refuse to accept it as an explanation. So here is my explanation (like it or not, I really don't care...I'm just doing this for fun): While Ripley was rescuing Newt, before Bishop started circling (you'll remember at the end of Aliens she thought he left her, when in fact he was circling because the platform became shaky and unstable), an alien sneaked onto the rescue ship with two eggs (yes, two, despite the fact that only one was shown at the beginning of Alien, which explains how the face-hugger got two beings--two different eggs mean two different face-huggers), hid them, and immediately left the ship. Soon after, the eggs open and the face-huggers leave the rescue ship and search the Sulaco until they find the sleeping survivors. And there you have it, my simple explanation. Point is, they never explain to you what happened, so you have to use your imagination. And if you can get over the flawed beginning, it's actually a pretty good film. It's too bad about the scenes that were reportedly cut (see \\"alternate versions\\") though. They would have made a good movie great. Overall, not as good as its predecessors, but definitely worthy of being the third (and what should have been the final) chapter in the Alien series.<br /><br />Alien: Resurrection is the long awaited fourth instalment in the Alien series. Alien3, Alien: Resurrection's predecessor didn't do too well with the critics. And neither did this movie. But, in fact, I liked it. The script may be clunky at times but still planned well by writer Joss Whedon and the feeling of total unrealistic cheese is there sometimes, unlike the first two Alien movies where it really felt like it was happening. But, Alien: Resurrection is so irresistibly entertaining and full of energy that you can't really dislike it too much. It's entertaining, loud and unashamed of what it is - a good piece of Friday night entertainment. The atmosphere is incredibly tense and the characters all bring up plenty of surprises. Even if the performances aren't perfect and the story isn't oh-so-original, there is a thrilling underwater chase through a kitchen and some awesome alien effects and make-up, which make the movie cool enough for me to watch twice! Put together on an impressive DVD box set, this is essential science fiction entertainment.never explain to you what happened, so you have to use your imagination. And if you can get over the flawed beginning, it's actually a pretty good film. It's too bad about the scenes that were reportedly cut (see \\"alternate versions\\") though. They would have made a good movie great. Overall, not as good as its predecessors, but definitely worthy of being the third (and what should have been the final) chapter in the Alien series. <br />Alien: Resurrection is the long awaited fourth instalment in the Alien series. Alien3, Alien: Resurrection's predecessor didn't do too well with the critics. And neither did this movie. But, in fact, I liked it. The script may be clunky at times but still planned well by writer Joss Whedon and the feeling of total unrealistic cheese is there sometimes, unlike the first two Alien movies where it really felt like it was happening. But, Alien: Resurrection is so irresistibly entertaining and full of energy that you can't really dislike it too much. B0009MAP9A|4.0|Despite what you might hear from other reviewers, this album still touches on issues that rule the day even now.  The title track is easy to cite, but it really is on tracks like \\"With God On Our Side\\" and \\"Hattie Carroll\\" that time vindicates best.  For all the countlesss albums made by others that were specifically designed to make a strong political statement, none were able to distill the transient issues of the time into bigger principles, and to tie them to basic human issues like this.  Racism, political inertia, the economic struggles of the working class are all presented here in stories of their time, but not done in such a way as to be dated by them.  It should be recalled that Dylan did his political stuff in the early sixties; several years before the nation went that way en masse.  By the time the country became overtly politically charged, Dylan had long moved on, and was singing about Country Pie.  To accuse him of milking a trend is a joke.  If anything, he was criticized for not jumping back in when the country caught up with him. <br /> <br />The timeless themes here are not just a function of the subject matter, but also a function of the fact that Dylan always tried to use time-tested musical forms to tell the story...the folk songs of Ireland, the blues of the American south, even some of the free-form improv stuff of jazz.  He was a student of all types of folk music, and this album shows how astute his observations were.  He wanted his musical language to borrow from that which was proven by history, and he did it as well on this album as any. <br /> <br />I also want to suggest this album foreshadows the focus on personal relationships that would come to dominate the bulk of his career.  \\"Spanish Leather\\" is a story of a love in limbo - and ultimately in vain - that uses universal themes and his unique keen insight on it to great effect.  It's greatness is revealed by the fact that the song takes many many listens to reveal its full scope. <br /> <br />The remaster series, in my opinion, are more for the pleasure of audiophiles.  Dylan - especially in this era - never really spent a ton of time on the details of recording.  His decision to do so never negatively impacted fan's enjoyment of the work.  Adding more clarity to it now will do little to impact it positiively.  Get this CD so that the source will be as loud in your headphones as the other re-issues.  That seems to be the best reason to get it. <br /> <br />New Dylan fans should pick this up with Freewheelin' to get the \\"protest\\" era's best stuff.  After that, you will find his genius focused upon interpersonal relations, and he never really returns to the political with this intensity.  It is important if only for that.

B000024D4R|5.0|While it is just a small step below Pink Floyd's previous masterpieces Dark Side of the Moon and Wish You Were Here, Animals is nonetheless worthy of the great praise that it so seldom receives.  Like DSOTM and WYWH, Animals is a concept album, but it is much darker than any other Floyd Album, and beautifully summarizes the social, political, and economic horrors of 20th Century capitalism without seeming at all comtemporary.  Although it is loosely based on George Orwell's Animal Farm, it is still stunningly original and a mindblowing experience from start to finish.  Dogs is one of the greatest Pink Floyd songs ever featuring one of Gilmour's finest solos, and both Pigs and Sheep are infectious rockers that make this album much more aggressive than previous Floyd works.  And although they are easily ignored, Pigs on the Wing Parts 1 and 2 serve as an amazingly simple yet beautiful way for the album to start and end.  Strongly recommended for anyone whose level of thought exceeds MTV and sitcoms and would like to listen to a work of art that will undoubtedly change their life.

0345404475|4.0|I usually leave the Science Fiction reading to my husband, as the complex technical mumbo-jumbo often alienates me, so to speak.  But I've more and more warmed to books with an anti-utopia feel to them.  I started with Orwell's 1984 and stumbled into the world of Phillip K. Dick.  It seems, through PKD, I have found just the right mix of fantasy and philosophy to keep me interested.  This is the kind of Science Fiction novel I would write. <br /> <br />\\"Androids\\" takes place in a not-too-distant future on an earth that is enshrouded in a radioactive cloud following a third and final world war \\"Terminus\\" (you don't need a Latin class to understand what that means).  Most of the people have fled the planet to strke up colonies on other planets, like Mars, and almost all animals have become extinct or so precious that they are bought, traded, auctioned, or financed like rare automobiles or baseball cards.  People who can't afford to purchase a live animal of their own (even spiders are priced at over $100), can purchase a synthetic \\"electric\\" animal that fools no one upon cursory inspection, but don't make much for status symbols.  How ironic that today we view our homes and cars in the same way these characters view animals we slaughter or stamp under our shoes on a daily basis! <br /> <br />In a post-apocalyptic world, people who emmigrate to other planetary colonies get to take with them android servants that have been banned on Earth because of the fear that they could wreak havoc among human civilization (although the fact that they have 4 year lifespans should be enough to alleviate our concerns, but this is never addressed).  So Rick Deckard, our protagonist, is a Bounty Hunter with the charge of tracking down and \\"retiring\\" rogue androids who have escaped the colonies.  They are given polygraph-like tests to determine whether they have the human trait of empathy, which seperates the \\"andys\\" from the human beings. <br /> <br />The novel frequently makes philosophical arguments of what it's like to be human, and how it is possible that our very own creations have the potential to become just like us.  I also couldn't help but observe the fact that if these androids are escaping what they feel is a life of servitude and pain on another planet, then they must also feel empathy in some minute way- empathy for those who suffer far worse hardships.  Otherwise, they would never question their existence and just remain servile drones. <br /> <br />Anyway, there were a few flaws- the dialogue was empty and there was very little suspense.  Events ran smack-dab into one another and hardly allowed enough time for us to grasp one concept before heading into the next.  I also felt the whole \\"religious experience\\" ending was a bit muddled, but it came together perfectly by the end, leaving a feeling that perhaps things will be better for Rick and his wife, even if they still have an electric animal. <br /> <br />While not perfect, \\"Do Androids Dream...\\" has proven a perfect springboard for me to explore more of the Science Fiction world, and my next choice will likely be a Phillip K. Dick novel.

B000002H33|5.0|This is one of the very best albums ever produced and ever written.<br /><br />I remember in high school when the hardest song I ever listened to was The Beatles' Helter Skelter. It could be complex, well composed, and interesting to listen to.<br /><br />Since Master, I have broadened my horizons greatly allowing all sorts of different music to come and entertain these ears. However infrequently I listen to Master anymore isn't a result of losing interest in the album. Rather it's because every time I hear it, I get depressed about how bad everything else is. Well, that's a slight exaggeration, but not far from the truth!<br /><br />Master of Puppets is a metamorphic conglomeration of every high-speed riff that actually sounds good, with a younger James's wailing about the horrors of life...I can almost feel the tectonic plates shifting beneath my speakers.<br /><br />What else about this album that's so great? Well, the art packaging inside the book is pretty minimalistic, but the cover of the album is one of the greatest designed covers for any album on earth. Look closely at the left and center crosses: there is a soldier's helmet and dogtags on these crosses, respectively. B000002H2H|5.0|Ride the Lightning -- one of two of the heaviest Tallica albums (the other being Puppets) that has actual influences coming from the bassist, Cliff Burton who was classically trained. In fact, musical theory classes at the University of Colorado analyze For Whom the Bell Tolls. The songs are more classically complex rather than merely utilizing classical chord progressions.<br /><br />This album is 7/8ths perfect: Trapped Under Ice is regarded by the band as filler.  However much I hate to agree, I listen to this album straight through every time.<br /><br />Listening to Ride the Lightning is like taking a weather course.  The band throws you fire, lightning, death, night, ice water, air, earth, and a digression into mythology.  As a whole, Metallica's albums can be classified as chrysology: the study of precious metal.<br /><br />I was in France when I purchased my first Metallica album, in 1991. I almost bought Lightning simply because it had the coolest artwork on the cover, but I ended up going with the Black album (best 149 Francs I ever spent!). I don't think I could've appreciated this album back then as I do now.
B00004Z46W|4.0|To worship at the sonic temple of King Crimson always meant dispensing with preconceived notions, and Fripp and company proved more than ready to lay waste to their more staid contemporaries on this 1973 masterwork.<br /><br />The recording itself, which won technical awards way back in 1973, is clear as bell: every nuance from Jamie Muir's eccentric percussion to John Wetton's vocal growls comes through crisply (no doubt a better vocalist for his going at it with Roger Chapman during his stint in the mighty Family before joining KC.) Bill Bruford obviously loved this band, and unfettered of the art-rock formula that Yes was starting to fall into, he unleashes some powerful drumming that, along with Wetton's meaty bass lines, help hold together this sonic supernova. David Cross sometimes plays against Fripp's leads with great effect, his violin swooping and soaring like a flying prehistoric reptile chasing its next meal.<br /><br />And Fripp, well, praise be to whatever the source of his muse here, for it is both balm to the jaded nerves of those disenfranchised by the corporate takeover of FM radio and anathema to the lobotomized program directors who have laid waste to creative playlists.<br /><br />I'm keeping a star back because the two versions of the title track sometimes veer off so far that the music dissolves into a vapor. Still the explosiveness of Easy Money clears the mind and feeds one's bellicose instincts, while Exiles calms the soul of the wanderer and hermit found somewhere deep down in us all.<br /><br />Like any King Crimson outing, \\"Larks Tongues in Aspic\\" is not everyone's cup of tea, but everyone needs to sample this one as a reminder of the power of imagination fueled by technique.

This is probably the catchiest song on here. <br /> <br />Pleasure Dome: In my opinion, the BEST song on this album. Period. Everything is awesome. Alex's drumming on this one is among the best in the entire Van Halen catalogue, and towards the mid section everyone else backs off some to let Ed do his thing. And God does he ever. He gets a bout not once, but twice before they end it. Truly spellbinding. <br /> <br />In N' Out: This is my least favorite song on the album. It isn't bad at all, it just doesn't stand as strong as the others. B0009353IW|5.0|This is the first time I have ever been moved to write a review, but I am just knocked out by \\"Chavez Ravine.\\"  I have been listening to it almost continuously for the five days since I purchased it, and I don't see stopping any time soon. <br /> <br />I'm a huge baseball fan, but I didn't know much about the sorry story of the disenfranchisement of the largely Hispanic community at Chavez Ravine to make way for Dodger Stadium.  The CD takes you through a cultural and political history of the area, starting with the so-called \\"Zoot Suit\\" riots during World War II, which branded the area as undesirable; the proposal for public housing in the area that wound up costing LA Public Housing Director Frank Wilkinson 30 years of his life (\\"Don't Call Me Red\\"); and the cultural life of the barrio (\\"Muy Fifi\\" and the Lieber-Stoller classic \\"3 Cool Cats\\"). <br /> <br />Along the way we hear multiple perspectives -- the operator of the bulldozer who razed the houses in Chavez Ravine (\\"It's Just Work for Me\\") and Wilkinson, understand the cultural conflict between Asian and Mexican Americans (\\"Chinito Chinito\\"), and finally, in  a ballad that leaves me weepy every time I hear it, a Dodger Stadium parking lot attendant, born in Chavez Ravine, who places his childhood memories at ballpark landmarks -- his home at 3rd base, his first kiss on the first base line -- while ruefully remembering \\"a place you don't know, up a road you can't go.\\" <br /> <br />This is a perspective most of us aren't familiar with -- the disenfranchisement of the poor in the name of progress in the 1950s, but after you've listened to this CD, you get it, and your body moves to the beat of the long-gone neighborhood.   <br /> <br />Don't miss this.
0767847431|3.0|just so you know people. the full frame version is not pan & scan, but the original edit before the top and bottom of the frame were matted out for theatrical release. that's right the top and bottom of the frame is cut for the widescreen version unlike the more common cutting at the sides known as pan & scan. Harryhausen was aware that his films were going to be shown on tv so he tried to keep the original films unmatted for future tv showings. So far this movie is the only one that I know of that carries this version. My advice is if you have a 4:3 tv set then I highly recommend watching it in full frame. however if you 16x9 set then it would propably be better to watch it in the matted widescreen 'anamorphic' version to get more detail & better picture.

B0001WTVUW|4.0|It may be the most telling tribute to the power of \\"The Day After\\" that 22 years later people still remember where they were when they saw it. But its implicit criticism of the political \\"wisdom\\" of the day is of a boldness and ferocity with few equals in television history. But it behooves us to consider why. It's not because all the nuclear warheads detonated during it were hurled into the sun by the World Peace Fairy. It's because Mikhail Gorbachev didn't delude himself into thinking that the Soviet Union could continue pursuing its Cold War policies without destroying itself. Insert Iraq analogy here. <br /> <br />So our decline into savagery probably won't happen overnight. It will proceed by steps. Letting the rights to poison the environment go the highest bidder in the interest of \\"economic development\\". The lazy or fearful surrender of our civil liberties in the name of \\"security\\". B00005QDW5|3.0|If you're already well-versed with the PF catalog then this double set is probably a waste of your time. In order to pack as many songs as they could into 2 CD's, the producers of Echoes trimmed down several songs from their original versions, most notably Shine on You Crazy Diamond. Not only are they missing the last few parts of the song (they only include 1-7), but they cut out the guitar solo before the first lyrical verse. For me, it was very painful to listen to this song, expecting the solo I knew so well, only to be greeted by the first verse of lyrics. If you've never heard the song before, then obviously this won't affect you, but for an experienced listener the song cuts that are made are very annoying. They immediately detract from the integrity of the song, making it feel more like a radio edit than the full track it was intended to be.  <br /> <br />Another complaint I have about Echoes is the arrangement and ordering of the songs. The producers obviously tried to include very diverse selections from all versions of Floyd (with/without Syd Barrett, Roger Waters, etc.). While this is seemingly a good idea, the actual order the songs are placed on these CDs seems to defy obvious logic--it just seems completely random. This is a shame, since Pink Floyd has had one of the most unique evolutions as a band in both songwriting and style. <br /> <br />In my opinion, instead of releasing Echoes, the producers should have released a 3-CD set that better highlighted the evolution of the band. The first CD would include their early tunes, the psychadelic, spacey, and most experimental side of the band. This time period covers everything from Piper up to and including Meddle, which is where their transition into more pointed, melodic music occurred. CD 2 would start off with DSOTM, and include the highlights of their next 3 major albums: Wish You Were Here, Animals, and The Wall. The last CD in this 3-CD set I'm dreaming of would start off with the Final Cut (rightbefore this album, the band started to break up, and this is Waters' last PF record) and include work from the post-Waters PF era. Personally, I'm not as huge a fan of the post-Waters Pink Floyd, but hey, it's still Pink Floyd. <br /> <br />Instead of an idea similar to this, however, Echoes is just a random smattering of specific moments in PF's great career. It's hard (actually impossible) to capture the greatness of Pink Floyd in just 2 or 3 CD's, but I still think Echoes could have been done better. If you're new to Pink Floyd, then yes, it's a good introduction to the band's range of sounds and includes many musical highlights, therefore a recommended buy. But for experienced PF listeners, don't bother with this unless you absolutely need the complete catalog.
0141301155|4.0|In children's literature, the hero often faces extreme hardship.  Most often, his or her parents are killed and the hero is left as an orphan, dealing with evil stepparents or the like.  Charlie Bucket is spared that fate - both his parents are still living.  In fact, Charlie is a member of a large, loving household.  The Buckets problem is that they are poor - very, very, very poor.  They are starving, in fact.  Reading this book as an adult, it is striking to see just how extreme their suffering is.  They all suffer from malnutrition; Charlie has to leave early for school because, if he runs, he will pass out from exhaustion. <br /> <br />The cruelty of their starvation is exacerbated because they live right next to the most famous chocolate factory in the world.  Charlie loves chocolate more than anything else, but can only afford one bar a year - on his birthday.   When Willy Wonka announces that he has hidden five golden tickets to his factory in chocolate bars all over the world, chances look pretty slim that Charlie will find one.  However, considering the name of the book is Charlie and the Chocolate Factory, you can guess how it turns out. <br /> <br />The movie is such a classic that it is hard to come to this book without preconceptions.  Now, with the new movie, there is a danger that the book may get lost in the shuffle.  That is a shame.  The book stands on its own and should be read first.  For one thing, the book is less scary than the movie - the Oompa-Loompas are far less creepy.  For another, Roald Dahl's style is fun enough to be interesting to adults as well as children.  One danger though - reading this book makes you crave chocolate! <br />
B00004SVID|5.0|I'll start this off by saying that I already own The Wall studio version, and enjoy it very much. However, I happily consider this LIVE version of The Wall to be an upgrade. The fact that it's live, with an audience adds more energy to the feel of the album, not to mention hearing some different, slightly more fleshed-out instrumental segments on songs like Run Like Hell, Another Brick in the Wall, and Comfortably Numb. The booklets included in the CD case are also a bonus. <br /> <br />However, my favorite part of this live recording is a subtle point, but it's also the main reason that I prefer this version to the studio one: Roger Waters' vocal intensity. Here, he gives a truly talented performance. I'm not just talking about hitting all the notes, which he does, but more so with the emotion and feeling in his words. You can hear his sarcasm on Happiest Days of Our Lives, his authoritarian snarl on Run Like Hell, and the confusion and hysteria on The Trial, among many other things. Not that this sort of vocal presence is absent from the studio recording, but the fact that this version is live gives they lyrical delivery added integrity and poignance. I've always loved the lyrics on The Wall, and they've never caught my attention as faithfully as they have on this double CD.  <br /> <br />So if you already own The Wall, I'd recommend this as a noticable upgrade. If you don't own The Wall studio version, then this is definitely a good buy, and very much well worth your money. Recommended either way.

B000022TSY|5.0|With a soundtrack featuring \\"If Six Was Nine\\" by Jimi Hendrix, \\"Weight\\" by The Band, \\"Born to Be Wild\\" and \\"The Pusher\\" by Steppenwolf, and excellent performances by Peter Fonda and Dennis Hopper as well as Jack Nicholson, this film is a true masterpiece. Usually called \\"The original biker movie\\", Easy Rider is about two bikers from L.A. who take off on a cross-country trip to New Orleans for Mardi Gras. On the way, they make some new friends, one in particular named George Hansen played by Jack Nicholson, the \\"lawyer with the ACLU\\". Dennis Hopper won \\"Best New Director\\" at the 1969 Cannes Film Festival for his work on this movie. This movie also introduced the world to 3 time Academy Award winner Jack Nicholson. Also, this film was the first film that featured actors smoking REAL marijuana on screen. Yes, they were actually stoned, believe it or not. The 35th anniversary DVD is a re-release of the 30th anniversary edition. The only difference is that it features the Easy Rider soundtrack on CD and contains the 80-page British Film Institute Modern Classic book \\"Easy Rider\\". The transfer is flawless, especially for a 60's film. The 30th anniversary DVD contains a 1.85:1 widescreen presentation with Dolby Digital 5.1 and Dolby Surround 2.0 soundtracks, and extras such as the documentary \\"Easy Rider: Shaking the Cage\\", and a commentary by Dennis Hopper. So, take it from me, a 16 year old film buff: This movie is a true classic, and a worthy addition for anyone's film collection.

B00004TRD8|5.0|There's already great reviews regarding the movie, so I'm just going to add the differences between the R1 DVDs.<br /><br />DIFFERENCES BETWEEN THE ULTIMATE EDITION and EXTREME EDITION DVD:<br /><br />Extreme has better sound and picture quality, but you don't really notice unless you are watching it on a HUGE screen with a very expensive Dolby Digital 5.1 surround sound system (THX approved of course), and have a guy that produced the DVD sitting next to you pointing out the VERY slight differences in quality.<br /><br />If I remember correctly, the Extreme edition is the only release that has a director's commentary featuring Cameron and William Wisher. UE has a commentary featuring lots of cast and crew that's pieced together from other interviews.<br /><br />The Extreme Edition has lots of making of and behind the scenes clips that can be accessed right from the movie. As you're watching, a Cyberdyne logo will appear up in the corner of the screen. If you click on it, it'll take you to extra info about that particular scene, behind the scenes footage, interviews, etc. I think some of the clips are different from those included in the extras of the UE version, and some are the same. When the clip is done, it'll return you right to the part of the movie you were at, and continue the movie. (There's also a menu page where these clips can be accessed directly without having to go into the movie.)<br /><br />Extreme also has DVD-ROM features that Ultimate doesn't have, such as a Windows Media Player 9 High-Definition transfer of the 139 minute theatrical cut. Extreme also has a 9-10 minute montage of behind the scenes clips that aren't on UE.<br /><br />Another difference between the two is that the UE contains the 139 minute theatrical cut, 152 minute director's cut, AND 156 minute extended director's cut of the film (it has the alternate ending and a scene that shows the T-1000 searching John's room), while the Extreme only has the 139 and 152 minute versions of the film. The 156 minute version is an easter egg on the UE though, which can be accessed on Disc 1/Side 1.<br /><br />Where is it?<br />Select the \\"Special Edition\\" option at the main menu. Enter 8, 29, 97 at the special edition screen to access the \\"Extended Special Edition\\" version of the film.<br /><br />What is it?<br />Two extra scenes will appear during the special edition (director's cut) version of the movie.<br /><br />Note: Some remote controls require the +10 button to be used to enter the numbers, other DVD players will need to have Enter pressed after each individual digit.<br /><br />As for soundtracks, the UE features: Dolby EX 6.1, DTS ES 6.1, Dolby Digital 2.0 and the cast and crew commentary.<br /><br />The Extreme features a Dolby Digital EX 5.1 soundtrack, Dolby headphone audio track, and the Cameron commentary.<br /><br />Ultimate has the better \\"extras\\", and the 156 minute cut of the film.<br /><br />So it's up to you. Go for the same film with less extras (Extreme), or the same film with more extras (Ultimate).<br /><br />However, if you love the UE, I'd wait for the movie to hit a Hi-Definition format before you go buying the movie again.on the UE though, which can be accessed on Disc 1/Side 1.    Where is it?  Select the \\"Special Edition\\" option at the main menu. Enter 8, 29, 97 at the special edition screen to access the \\"Extended Special Edition\\" version of the film.    What is it?  Two extra scenes will appear during the special edition (director's cut) version of the movie.    Note: Some remote controls require the +10 button to be used to enter the numbers, other DVD players will need to have Enter pressed after each individual digit.     As for soundtracks, the UE features: Dolby EX 6.1, DTS ES 6.1, Dolby Digital 2.0 and the cast and crew commentary.    The Extreme features a Dolby Digital EX 5.1 soundtrack, Dolby headphone audio track, and the Cameron commentary.     Ultimate has the better \\"extras\\", and the 156 minute cut of the film.    So it's up to you. Go for the same film with less extras (Extreme), or the same film with more extras (Ultimate).     However, if you love the UE, I'd wait for the movie to hit a Hi-Definition format before you go buying the movie again.

0515123447|5.0|Lee Child has written an amazing first novel. His main character Jack Reacher is not only believable but likeable. We are able to identify with him and be on his side from the outset. An honorable man who was released from the Military after an exemplary career because there was nothing left to do in the now peaceful world. Reacher being arrested in the first line of the novel made for a fast start to what proved to be a fast paced and adrenaline filled ride. <br /> <br />Reacher is accused of being in the wrong place at the wrong time. He arrived into the small Georgia town in his new life as a drifter, after being cut loose from the army and his lengthy career there. Being the new guy in a small town would make  him stand out and be a plausible scapegoat. Reachers strong personality and Military Police background make his stoic acceptance of his early fate conceivable.   <br /> <br />It was somewhat unrealistic that Reacher and the Hubble could be put into the general prison population but that is where literary license comes into play. I think the portrayal of prison violence, although graphic, was very true. Having recently watched a documentary on prison violence, it really put the scene into perspective and provided a very realistic illustration. <br /> <br />Seeing Reacher's detective skills come into play was very impressive. Being allowed to have almost free reign over the investigation was unbelievable but worked for the story. Jack Reacher works as a big, scary police officer. <br /> <br />I was left thinking throughout this book as to the next step. As I have said in previous reviews of other books, I don't really try to figure the mysteries out. My preference is to let the auther weave the tale of suspense and I get to enjoy the ride. <br /> <br />This is the first in the Jack Reacher series and has proven to be a very fine novel. The series should stand out amongst it's peers as one of the best. I look forward to reading more from Lee Child seeing thecontinual growth of Jack Reacher.
B00097DX3U|5.0|There's been a lot said about Audioslave. Called a \\"supergroup\\" by some, and - more recently - corporate sell-outs by others.  It seems that some are unwilling to accept that Rage Against The Machine is no more.  Comparisons are bound to exist, just because Audioslave is definitely influenced by both of its predecessors, Rage and Soundgarden. But while those bands were great, their time has past, and it is now the time of Audioslave.   <br /> <br />What we get from this album is a more together, tightly knit, and somewhat more playful sound than their self-ttled debut. The band takes a more melodic approach here, and it pays off. Chris Cornell still bangs out explosive yet soulful vocals, and Tom Morello has matured and improved upon his guitar work from their previous album.  The bass and drum work is flawless. From the group that gave us a perfect soundtrack to roadtrips from their debut, we get another great album, certainly equal in worth to that debut. <br /> <br />Track by track, here's the breakdown: <br />1. Your Time Has Come - energetic opener, colliding Chris Cornell's soulful lyrics with very Rage reminiscent music, as well as a very Morello-esque solo. Great way to start an album. <br />2. Out of Exile - starts out slow, builds up, then reverts to slow during the verses. Nice verses, soulful chorus, and an effects-laden solo make this a great song to listen to. <br />3. Be Yourself - the first single off this album.  No matter how many times I hear this song, I still want more. Great guitar work, somewhat simple though it may be, builds to a Rage-reminiscent solo. Cornell's vocals shine as soulful and inspirational, and prove that the spirit of the band's predecessors are alive and well. <br />4. Doesn't Remind Me - a surprisingly melodic and playful effort by the band pays off on this track. The song almost sounds like a  Looking Glass effort (for those of you who enjoy old-school mellow rock). The solo starts off sounding oddly conventional of classicrock, touched by the grace of Tom Morello's unconventionalism. <br />5. Drown Me Slowly - starts off slow, but explodes into a very blues and classic rock reminiscent song. The solo is stand out for this track: it starts off with a DJ-scratching effect laid over a great bass line, followed by Morello's effects-laden mania. Great track.  <br />6. Heaven's Dead - slower track, but is so to let Chris Cornell belt out some great vocals. Accompanied by his bandmates, this song lives up to greatness that \\"I Am The Highway\\" created for their first release. <br />7. The Worm - great vocals, great music, great coupling, nuff said. <br />8. Man or Animal - high energy track, very reminiscent of classic rock. Great vocals that blend well with the music. Unusual solo, but such is to be expected by Mr. Morello. <br />9. Yesterday or Tomorrow - begins with a good bass line. Slower song, great, thought-provoking vocals. Great build up during the bridge to a mellow solo. <br />10. Dandelion - another melodic song.  Great vocals, possibly about a daughter.  Another playful song, that shows the band can just have fun while kicking ass. <br />11. #1 Zero - Another slower paced song, the vocals couple well with \\"What You Are\\" from their previous release.  Very ethereal guitar work.  Song is driven by powerful vocals. <br />12. The Curse - the final and longest track on the album. Great track to end things on. It just sounds like it was made to end an album. Solo starts slow, and ends very fast and crazy. As I said before, a great way to end the album. <br /> <br />Audioslave has given us another gem with Out of Exile.  A tight album, which the band acheiving new levels of harmony. This album is a must own for any Audioslave fan, and a great addition to any music collection.

B000000W5N|5.0|By 1971, it was clear that stardom, drug abuse, Brian Jones' death, and Altamont had huge impacts on the Stones. The resulting album was Sticky Fingers, a true masterwork. Easily the best by the Rolling Stones, this comes close to being my favorite album of all time.<br />1. Brown Sugar: 10/10. This one's a classic cut. A disturbingly exuberant fusion of soul and rock with some of the dirtiest lyrics in Stones history, there's no doubt that this works perfectly. Play it at a party, you'll get good reaction. This also happens to be the only song here with any optimism.<br />2. Sway: 10/10. Though those who only know the Stones from what gets played on the radio will never have heard it, Sway is a fan favorite and rightfully so. Besides containing Mick Taylor's defining moment as a guitarist, Mick Jagger's tortured screams and a brilliant string arrangement, it's also extremely well-written.<br />3. Wild Horses: 10/10. This is one of those rare Stones ballads that actually has a remote amount of emotional impact on me. (Most the rest, namely Angie and Ruby Tuesday, seemed forced). Not only does this country ballad tug at the heartstrings, it totally rips them to shreds. A worthy classic.<br />4. Can't You Hear Me Knocking: 10/10. Another one of the alltime greats. It starts as an aggresive rocker, but don't let that fool you. After the song's more traditional first half, it becomes a jazz/Latin jam! Not only does Bobby Keyes play the best damn sax solo on a Stones album, Keef matches it with his Latin guitar, sounding like Santana. Brilliant.<br />5. You Gotta Move: 6.5/10. You don't know how disappointed I was the first time I heard this song. Though it isn't bad, it sounds awful when heard after Can't You Hear Me Knockin'. I believe that this would've worked on Beggars Banquet, though it was obviously too late to include it on that disc. Oh well.<br />6. Bitch: 10/10. The BEST STONES SONG PERIOD!!!!! It's so energetic, it's like it'll explode at any second. It truly sounds like Motown...from Hell!!! (Take one of their best lines, \\"This must be love/it's a bitch!\\") With it's constant references to how drugs can screw you up, it's the definitive piece of the album and a hint at the last three songs.<br />7. I Got the Blues: 9/10. Mick's affected vocals really send this to the top, as well as a fine organ solo. Though it's not the most original song in existance, you gotta love the way Mick belts it out.<br />8. Sister Morphine: 10/10. The Rolling Stones, among rock's most notorious drug abusers, come up with a haunting O.D. ballad with some of the best guitar in Stones history. But this song is supposed to be listened to for the lyrics themselves. Jagger delivers his creepy tale in a dramatic fashion, paired with some truly frightening imagery. Best of all, it never seems over the top. Kicks off a suite of three drug-influenced songs.<br />9. Dead Flowers: 10/10. A funny country parody. Mick once said that he could never listen to country without cracking up. As a result, the send-up is a hilarious spoof of virtually every country cliche in the book. It provides the necessary lighter passage between epics Sister Morphine and Moonlight Mile. The second of the \\"Drug Suite\\".<br />10. Moonlight Mile: 10/10. Far and away the best, most affecting ballad the Stones ever pulled. Like Can't You Hear Me Knocking, Moonlight Mile is like no Stones song before or after it. An epic about drugs, death and ultimate redemption, it will follow you forever. A fitting closer to Sticky Fingers, and arguably their most beautiful song ever.<br />The verdict: buy it!om Hell!!! (Take one of their best lines, \\"This must be love/it's a bitch!\\") With it's constant references to how drugs can screw you up, it's the definitive piece of the album and a hint at the last three songs.  7. I Got the Blues: 9/10. Mick's affected vocals really send this to the top, as well as a fine organ solo. Though it's not the most original song in existance, you gotta love the way Mick belts it out.  8. Sister Morphine: 10/10. The Rolling Stones, among rock's most notorious drug abusers, come up with a haunting O.D. ballad with some of the best guitar in Stones history. But this song is supposed to be listened to for the lyrics themselves. Jagger delivers his creepy tale in a dramatic fashion, paired with some truly frightening imagery. Best of all, it never seems over the top. Kicks off a suite of three drug-influenced songs.  9. Dead Flowers: 10/10. A funny country parody. Mick once said that he could never listen to country without cracking up. As a result, the send-up is a hilarious spoof of virtually every country cliche in the book. It provides the necessary lighter passage between epics Sister Morphine and Moonlight Mile. The second of the \\"Drug Suite\\".  10. Moonlight Mile: 10/10. Far and away the best, most affecting ballad the Stones ever pulled. Like Can't You Hear Me Knocking, Moonlight Mile is like no Stones song before or after it. An epic about drugs, death and ultimate redemption, it will follow you forever. A fitting closer to Sticky Fingers, and arguably their most beautiful song ever.  The verdict: buy it!

0312323859|5.0|I must admit, while reading Emily Giffin's \\"Something Borrowed,\\" I didn't care very much for Darcy at all (though I did LOVE the book).  But after reading \\"Something Blue,\\" I have come to absolutely love her!  \\"Something Blue\\" finds Darcy Rhone newly pregnant--and alone.  She has lost virtually all of her friends, and her parents do not approve of, nor do they have compassion for, Darcy and her impending motherhood.  Desperate for a change in her shallow existence, Darcy makes an impulsive move to London and stays with her childhood friend, Ethan, much to his dismay.  She tells Ethan that her stay is \\"just a short visit,\\" no longer than a month, although she knows in her mind that she plans on staying in London a lot longer than a month.  Along the way, the reader will grow to understand Darcy as a person, and appreciate her genuine strive for change in a world where everyone is so focused on societal status and outward appearance.  The reader will also fall completely in love with Ethan, someone who is distant with Darcy in the beginning, but grows to genuinely admire her for the good-hearted, nurturing person she truly is inside; and he eventually comes to cherish the sweet, innocent closeness that blossoms between them.  This sequel is a winner!  It is warm and charming, a story about the true meaning of friendship and love, and the power they have to change us all.  I do hope Emily Giffin's admirable, lovable characters pop up again in a new book sometime soon!  Highly recommended!
B00006RU5B|5.0|As a HUGE fan of both Rage Against the Machine and Soundgarden, it was no suprise to me that this album would kick ass. These are actually the worst songs on the album (it might just be because they came after four lively songs.) But, out of the two, Getaway Car is better, being sort of blusey. <br />Overall, \\"Audioslave\\" is one of the best albums of 2002, and destined to be a rock classic, such as albums like \\"Led Zepplin 4,\\" \\"Nevermind,\\" and \\"Axis: Bold as Love.\\" <br /> <br />

B00005JNJT|4.0|WHAT A DIRECTOR!  WHAT A CAST! WHAT A SCRIPT!  WHAT A MOVIE!  I just saw BATMAN BEGINS last night and it's easily the best superhero movie I've ever seen, and maybe the best movie I've ever seen--period!    Val Kilmer and George Clooney were both good as Bruce Wayne/Batman, but Christian Bale is better looking, and goes from Batman to Bruce and back like he was born for the role!    Director Christopher Nolan's created a masterpiece here, with a terrific Hall of Fame cast with Michael Caine as butler Alfred, Gary Oldman as a wierd police buddy James Gordon--not yet Commissioner!--Morgan Freeman as a dedicated but isolated Wayne Corp staffer who becomes a sort of Tonto to Bale's Batman, and Liam Neesom as the main heavy, with Rutger Hauer hanging around as a corporate heavy at Wayne Corp.    The script keeps moving right along, and introduces an actor I've never seen before--Cillian Murphy--and boy, does this Irish kid steal the show as crazy Dr. Jonathan Crane alias the Scarecrow!!!  Murphy looks terrific, and he's one of the few modern actors with a great voice, which he uses to full effect in his terrifying role!    The music is great, too, and the only bad things about BATMAN BEGINS are that the action scenes area so fast you can never see what's going on, plus there's a stupid scene at Wayne Manor where  Wayne pretends to be drunk to run off some birthday party guests from impending danger--why couldn't a smooth guy like Wayne just send them off diplomatically???  Plus, Katie Holmes is a dud as love interest Rachel Dawes--she just doesn't look good enough for Bale!    But BATMAN BEGINS is beautifully filmed, and the movie keeps rolling along till the end when you're left wanting more--and that's the way movies are supposed to be!!!    BATMAN BEGINS IS THE BEST BATMAN MOVIE EVER MADE!!!    Chari Krishnan RESEARCHKING   TANGO2200@HOTMAIL.COM

B000002L7Y|4.0|It took me until April of 2005 to hear this album. I finally got the CD after many years of hearing Take On Me. This album personifies what some of the music in the '80s sounded like. They were known for Take on Me, the worldwide hit, but the rest of the album is full of strong light pop that's heavy on the keyboards and synthesizers. It was released in 1985, but the album has shades of the new wave sound of 1984 and what Cyndi Lauper was doing on her '83 debut. Both Love Is Reason, I Dream Myself Alive and Train Of Thought are superb dance pop songs that match well with the hits from this debut.  I still love the dramatic title song Hunting High and Low, which still is timeless a good 20 years later. The orchestra sound lush and fabulous on this song. Morten Harket has such a nice falsetto that cuts well through the songs. The last song Here I Stand and Face the Rain may have been the benchmark to their later, more mature sounds of the '90s and now. A-ha's debut has such a catchiness to it that you wouldn't have thought that they were young when making this album. It is still an '80s classic and they're still recording 20 years later today!  Hearing this album makes things come full circle for them! It's had a strong endurance in pop music because of Take on Me and the other singles that came from it.

1573223026|3.0|Given his fondness for pop music, Nick Hornby may have been listening to Leonard Cohen, but he must have been channeling Gilbert O'Sullivan's \\"Alone Again, Naturally\\" when he conceived the plot of \\"A Long Way Down.\\"  Remember the lyric: \\"In a little while from now, / If I'm not feeling any less sour, / I promised myself to treat myself / And visit a nearby tower. / And climbing to the top, / Will throw myself off. . . .\\"  Four characters determine to do just that in Hornby's novel, until they start tripping over each other's neuroses on the roof of Toppers' House one fatal New Year's Eve.  Each of the four, even Maureen, the mother of a \\"sick child,\\" is savvy enough to know about the drug culture--a simple overdose is quick and relatively painless--so why do they insist on throwing themselves off a building?  This is but one of many questions that will have readers scratching their heads at \\"A Long Way Down.\\"  The good news for pedestrian traffic, but the bad news for the rest of us, is that, once having met, the four decide to put off the big event for six weeks, in which time they hope to bond as a \\"gang.\\"  Now there's a Dr. Phil-worthy goal for the wounded and depressed!<br /><br />Here's the gang: Matthew is an ex-talk show host who thinks his prison sentence for having slept with a 15-year-old is unfair because he was \\"not a criminal\\" but \\"a television performer who made a mistake.\\"  Maureen is a mother whose adult life has been taken up by the needs of her disabled son.  Jess is eighteen going on eight, a rebel without a clue who peppers her every sentence with four-letter words.  Finally, J. J., the obligatory American in the mix (think film rights), is a washed-up musician whose bathroom library extends to Richard Yates (foreshadowing?) and Pauline Kael.  None of these people has a compelling reason for taking his or her own life, but the reader might, after putting up with these whiners for 333 pages.<br /><br />Believe it or not, Nick Hornby is one of my favorite writers.  Nothing will take away my pleasure in having read \\"About a Boy,\\" \\"High Fidelity,\\" and \\"Fever Pitch.\\"  I wasn't crazy about \\"How to be Good,\\" but it had its moments.  Still, \\"A Long Way Down\\" is a major disappointment.  When I think of all the Grand Guignol possibilities for a plot such as this--the gang might have drawn lots to kill one another, for instance, or they could have made a pact not to die, only to expire en masse in a subway crash--I can't help but feel let down by Hornby's failure of the imagination.  I know others of the author's fans will be outraged by my defection (alone again, naturally), but I take comfort from the mostly negative reviews on Amazon's UK site.  Apparently, \\"A Long Way Down\\" is more popular in America than in his native England.  Cue the casting director.Nothing will take away my pleasure in having read \\"About a Boy,\\" \\"High Fidelity,\\" and \\"Fever Pitch.\\"  I wasn't crazy about \\"How to be Good,\\" but it had its moments. When I think of all the Grand Guignol possibilities for a plot such as this--the gang might have drawn lots to kill one another, for instance, or they could have made a pact not to die, only to expire en masse in a subway crash--I can't help but feel let down by Hornby's failure of the imagination. I feel that the makers of MOULIN ROUGE were probably trying to capture some of the big-hearted appeal of BRIGADOON when they created their fantasy world. 0316666343|5.0|I've read poorly written books and books I could not put down.  This one, in particular, is one I feel I will remember for a VERY long time.  In this novel, you meet a family, a neighborhood and strangers, all touched in some way by the death of a young girl.  You meet these people, learn some of their deepest darkest secrets, through a clever, insightful, tragically touching narration of the dead girl herself.  The novel follows her family and the others who've been drug along by the death as time passes, the girl's murder goes officially unsolved and her family struggles with loss, hate, love and the fact that life goes on.  If anyone ever asks me for a suggested book - I'll suggest this one.  If I ever meet the author, I'll tell her how much I admire her craftsmanship.
B00005JNJT|5.0|In Christopher Nolan's capable hands, the Batman franchise finally gets the formula right: drop the camp and embrace the darkness. \\"Origin of superhero\\" stories are notoriously difficult to do well because we all know where they're heading. Fortunately, Nolan and co-writer David Goyer have focused on the right thing: it's not just how Bruce Wayne becomes Batman, but why. Fear - where it comes from, how we beat it, and how it can be turned against others - is the theme here, and the Nolan/Goyer script is all the more interesting for it. They also recognise the imperative of telling a good story, offering us a well-crafted action/mystery plot which never drags despite needing to cover a lot of detail and carry a large freight of emotional and ideological complexity. Christian Bale is perfectly cast as the Dark Knight. He's fresh enough for most viewers to accept him as not just another Hollywood star in a rubber suit, and talented enough to pull off what ends up being a pretty complex character: both terrified and terrifying, sometimes simultaneously. He's impressive enough to be a credible superhero, yet fallible enough to be endearing. The big-name supporting cast are excellent, with the exception of the relentlessly banal Katie Holmes who plays Gotham's fearless, mob-busting ADA as Joey Potter in a nice suit. But she's a minor quibble. It all comes together here: a great script, engaging characters, wonderful production design, neatly deployed music (which right from the outset cleverly makes potentially tedious expository scenes feel like part of larger sequences), gorgeous cinematography, imaginative but never overpowering use of CGI, and perfect pacing. \\"Batman Begins\\" doesn't quite follow the mythology laid down in the graphic novels (which isn't internally consistent anyway) but it does prove what their readers have long known: it's not just the pretty pictures, guys - it's those wonderfully tortured characters, their desolate urban milieu, and the way it all grips your dark imagination. Nolan knows that, and he really nails it here. This is the Batman movie you've been waiting for.grips your dark imagination. Nolan knows that, and he really nails it here. This is the Batman movie you've been waiting for.
B0002Z0EYK|4.0|The Iliad is immortal, and the actors characterizations ofAchiles, Hector, Agamemnon, Menelaos, and even Helen were vivid and reasonably true to Homer's monumental tale. But Hollywood just can't leave a perfect story alone - so Achiles is given a hugely unlikely love interest and has his death by an arrow striking his only vulnerable body part, his heel, postponed until Troy fallsAnd where is the important doom predictor, Cassandra? Also, no swordsman in his right mind would resort to aerobatics to launch an attack - he woulf lose the power of his back and legs behind his sword stroke. Still, the faults are insignificant on the canvas of this grand epic.
B000062YB1|5.0|Since this was Slayer's first C.D. of the 1990's, some fans had to be worried about the direction of their music. But fear not.\\"Seasons in the Abyss\\" was just as intense and extreme as anything turned out in the `80's. This band did not change their sound and did not make their metal any slower- - not yet, (as of 1990) at least.<br /><br />Like all Slayer albums (especially from the 1980's), \\"Seasons in the Abyss\\" is brutal, relentless, addictive, and full of exquisite musicianship and frenetic guitar work. The drum work here is also very fast- - so fast that, if this were any other band, it would probably be the propelling force behind the beat. But since this is a Slayer album, it's the guitars that dominate the onslaught. I have no idea how Kerry King plays with this much force and precision. He could be totally screwing up his guitar part (by playing the wrong chord or something), and nobody would ever know because every riff runs, cascades, and flies by at a blinding, breakneck speed. At some points, the guitars are so fast that it's hard to distinguish one riff from another. The solos, however, aren't quite as scorching as before. They are slower and more professional.<br /><br />Next, it may be just my imagination, but I think Tom's voice is deeper, here. And since the music and vocals are this furious, Tom can't exactly sing a love song. Thus, the lyrics (i.e. \\"Razor's edge/outlines the dead/incisions in my head\\") are just as violent and gruesome as they ever were.<br /><br />Finally, an album isn't memorable if it is fast and heavy, but doesn't have any hooks. This album isn't typically heavy; it won't be stuck in your head all day and you can't really tap your foot to it, but \\"Seasons in the Abyss\\" is still very catchy, in its own way.<br /><br />Highlights include:<br /><br />\\"War Ensemble\\" opens with a really fast drum solo. This wild, all-over-the-place drumming remains throughout this song, but the opening riffs sort of sound like lasers, making this song not unlike Pantera's \\"Cowboys from Hell.\\" The guitars proceed to chug fast, then there's seamless tempo change and the riffs become lumbering. Up until the guitar solo near the end, it sort of sounds like drummer Dave Lombardo is trying desperately to keep up with the beat, which is driven by the axemen Kerry King and Jeff Hanneman.<br />\\"Spirit in Black\\" has more ferociously fast riffs. Even though these riffs sometimes sound almost punky, this is still a thrash song. I don't know any punk songs that have shrieking guitar solos.<br />\\"Expendable Youth\\" marries a pounding rhythm with Tom's squealing vocals, which echo \\"Jesus Saves\\" from the \\"Reign in Blood\\" album. There are some more super fast riffs (which blend into each other), as well as a pair of guitar solos.<br />\\"Dead Skin Mask\\" is a classic Slayer tune. It takes things down a notch and slows down the pace of the album, which was a good idea (so it doesn't become monotonous). This song begins with chugging riffs, then the riffs slow down even more, before going back to the speedier, opening riffs. Three more guitar solos are included; the first of which is only audible in the left headphone and sounds almost classical, a la Judas Priest. The second is audible in only the right headphone, and the third solo winds and bends and goes up and down.<br />\\"Hallowed Point\\" is another relentless sprint. It begins with Tom briefly breathing in, then the beat kicks in, the vocals begin almost immediately, and the song is rocketed full blast until around three minutes and twenty seconds, when there's a beat change.<br />\\"Born of Fire\\" has a 50-second long intro, which is shockingly slow and consists of just light strumming. Even when the beat becomes faster, this song has a mid-tempo pace. And I enjoy the deceptively kind lyrics that Tom spouts, here: \\"I need a friend; please be my companion.\\"<br /><br />Musically, \\"Seasons in the Abyss\\" is equally as great as \\"Reign in Blood;\\" but \\"RiB\\" was definitely a bigger milestone, so \\"Seasons\\" isn't quite as great as that 1986 landmark--but, then again, can you think of a C.D. that is?<br /><br />In conclusion, Slayer definitely live up to their name with this album. Everything on here (crazy drum work, careening guitar riffs and solos, tortured vocals, beat/tempo changes) makes \\"Seasons in the Abyss\\" another classic album from the thrash metal titans and essential listening for metalheads.ut, then again, can you think of a C.D. that is?    In conclusion, Slayer definitely live up to their name with this album. Everything on here (crazy drum work, careening guitar riffs and solos, tortured vocals, beat/tempo changes) makes \\"Seasons in the Abyss\\" another classic album from the thrash metal titans and essential listening for metalheads.

B00005A46T|3.0|In 1999, when their full-length debut was released, Slipknot were thought to be \\"a fluke.\\" 26 months later, the nine man band released their second C.D. Unfortunately, \\"Iowa\\" didn't get rid of those first critics, and it even brought on an additional label. In addition to being a fluke, these Iowans were now \\"an abomination.\\"<br /><br />It is my opinion/theory that, when Slipknot wrote \\"Iowa,\\" they tried to include every band member into about every song. The result is a sound which is cacophonous, monotonous, cluttered, and often ugly. Some parts of this album sound more like a garbage disposal than real music. This is not what heavy metal-even the most brutal heavy metal-is supposed to sound like.<br /><br />Three years after \\"Iowa,\\" \\"Vol. 3: The Subliminal Verses\\" was released. This album also alienated some \\"maggots\\" (Slipknot fans), but, compared to its predecessor, \\"Vol. 3\\" was quite refreshing; its guitar notes are a lot cleaner, and the overall sound is a lot more harmonic and focused. There are a few things that would explain this increase in quality: the band members took their time when writing it, and \\"Vol. 3\\" also fused some melody into the metal. However, I choose to believe that Slipknot achieved this improved sound by not being overly worried about making sure every band member contributes equally.<br /><br />\\"Iowa\\" does present a new sound for Slipknot; it's the band's most raw, hard hitting and brutal album to date. One could even argue that it is their most inspired record. However, a new sound doesn't always mean a step forward. Slipknot's sophomore outing shows no signs of maturity or any other form of musical growth. Slipknot simply took advantage of their talent, potential, and fame, and made a C.D. that I can best describe as \\"thrash/death metal gone overboard.\\" Now, since there are some OK guitar riffs and talented, all-over-the-place drumming, you might wonder why I call this album \\"ugly.\\" Well, aside from sounding cluttered, the biggest problem \\"Iowa\\" has might be Corey Taylor's overly violent, unnecessary, and usually out of place bellows.<br /><br />But I don't want to sound overly harsh. Most of \\"Iowa\\" is still listenable (especially if you're a metalhead), it has some other good qualities (like being Slipknot's most intense album), and, when you listen to them in small doses, there are even some good songs. The infamous \\"People=Sh-t\\" opens with a pounding rhythm and two ascending yells, \\"Disasterpiece\\" chugs and pounds equally as heavy, \\"Heretic Anthem\\" is another famous song and a centerpiece of Slipknot's live shows. It has two guitarists playing the same chugging riff, then the drums and vocals kick in and the beat explodes. This song has a nice steam rolling beat, stereo rattling guitar noise, and a mosh pit ready shout along chorus of: \\"If you're 555, I'm 666!\\" Whether you want it to or not, this song will get stuck in your head. Next, \\"Gently\\" might be the album's all around best song. Very dark and slow paced, with even some whispers and spoken word vocals. But \\"Gently\\" is my favorite because of the introspective and somber lyrics. Finally, the beginning of \\"Skin Ticket\\" is so eerily calm and restrained, it almost quivers, but the end is centered around Corey's throat-straining bellows. This part of the song makes for a very uneasy listen, but I enjoy how this song's lyrics change from \\"Come see my cage, built in MY GRAIN\\" to \\"Come see my cage, built in MIGRAINE.\\"<br /><br />So, \\"Iowa\\" definitely has some ugly and unlistenable parts, but when you listen to this album in small doses, and listen to the songs one-by-one, you'll realize this isn't terrible music, either. You can blame the ugly parts of this album on a number of things: an overpopulated band, a lack of melody, or on just sloppy songwriting- -but whatever the case, I think there's no denying that this album did not live up to the band's potential and it did not showcase their ability to write good music. So, \\"Iowa\\" was just a big mistake. This C.D. is worth checking out and it will probably keep you entertained for a few months, but if you want an album that's as brutal as but better than \\"Iowa,\\" get Slipknot's debut. In conclusion, unless you're a diehard maggot, you should skip this one.g out and it will probably keep you entertained for a few months, but if you want an album that's as brutal as but better than \\"Iowa,\\" get Slipknot's debut. In conclusion, unless you're a diehard maggot, you should skip this one.

B0007OCG4W|5.0|If you were expecting another cinematic exploration of the beautiful complexities of romantic relationships, you'd be well served to take a raincheck on CLOSER. This film is absolutely scathing as it delves into the sordid state of affairs revolving around the core group of four romantically (for total lack of a better description) linked individuals and leaves behind a rather bloodstained and bleak outlook on love and human nature. Yet, with all that being said, the absolutely transcendent performances from Jude Law, Julia Roberts, Natalie Portman and most notably the near charming ghoulishness of Clive Owen's alpha-male extraordinaire makes this film deceptively engaging. The dialogue isn't going to entice anyone's sweet old grandmother over for a viewing but it is unquestionably complex, humourous, appalling, and even comedic at times. It's akin to watching a train wreck; you know you should force yourself to look away but there's just something too magnetic about watching four beautiful love-challenged characters eviscerate one another with words and actions. It's one kick to the groin after another and an absolutely unflinching exploration of the dark side of destructive relationships and the personalities behind them. This motley crew of lovers has hardly any redeemable qualities about them. Everybody's a cheater, a bold-faced liar or a complete hypocrite at one moment or another. However, without the brilliant readings courtesy of the film's stars, the movie would be little more than couples swearing and doing unspeakable acts to one another. After watching CLOSER, you'll feel wiser, perhaps a little cynical, and hopefully properly-schooled in the art of how not to treat your significant other.   <br /> <br />

Expect a movie.<br /><br />This is a political thriller with high tech advetnure mixed in. The book is written around a Presidential campaign. The incumbent is pro NASA, and is being bashed by his opposition for NASA budget overruns and mission failures. Just when it seems the President will lose the election because of his support of NASA. Then NASA finds a meteor which contains a greater discovery.<br /><br />The President sends civilian scientist up to the meteor site in the artic to confirm NASA's findings. He wants to make sure the public believes that this is a real find, and the independent scientist will do that. Everyone is excited by the great find and confirm the meteor is as NASA claims.<br /><br />Then a little too late, the civilians uncover that the whole thing is just scientific hoax. But before the President can be briefed, the scientist become targets to a team of assassins. At this point two of the five civilians have been terminated and three are on the run across the Artic ice. Everyone our heros caome across and tell about this trickery end up dead. While running they not only need to get the truth out, but they need to determine who orchestrated this plot.

B000001DYJ|5.0|A lot of critics were very quick to dismiss this 1993 live album. Apparently it was some sort of sacriledge for Kiss to attempt to follow \\"Alive\\" and \\"Alive II\\".  Well, I picked up this album the year it came out, not knowing a whole lot about Kiss (I was one or two years old when \\"Alive\\" came out in 1975). And I mostly got it because the cover looked cool, I think.    But I loved it right away. Great sound, terrific, high voltage renditions of Kiss' best latter-day material...this is every bit as good as their first two live albums. Yeah, I said it.  These tight, focused performances are as gritty as anything Kiss has ever put out, and many of these live versions are even better and tougher than the studio originals. How can you resist stupid but exquisitely melodic and utterly lovable songs like \\"Take It Off\\" or \\"I Just Wanna\\"?  The chorus kinda sets the tone for this album. It goes something like this:  \\"I just wanna fuh- / I just wanna fuh- / I just wanna forget you!\\"    Gene Simmons roars his way through \\"Unholy\\" and \\"I Love It Loud\\", his demon persona in full flight even without the makeup, and lead guitarist Bruce Kulick admirably fills Ace Frehley's high-heeled boots.  This entire album is nothing but highlights, actually, from the opener \\"Creatures Of The Night\\" to the anthemic \\"God Gave Rock 'n' Roll To You\\" and an instrumental \\"Star Spangled Banner\\".  And in between you'll find terrific performances of the driving riff-rocker \\"Domino\\", the classic \\"Rock And Roll All Nite\\" and crowd-pleasers like \\"Lick It Up\\" and \\"I Was Made For Loving You\\". Vocally both Paul Stanley and Gene Simmons are in superb form, and Stanley's flexible tenor matches Simmons' huge, gravelly baritone perfectly. Alright, so \\"God Gave Rock 'n' Roll To You II\\" is pretty much a pop song, but it's a darn good one!    Big riffs, impossibly huge hooks, and lots of fist-pumping shout-along choruses have always been Kiss' trademark, and if you only ever get three (!) Kiss albums, make sure it's the three \\"Alive\\" CDs. Collectively they're better than any compilation, and this particular lightning bolt of a live album is just too much fun! You ought to have a special name for this kind of music. How about \\"bubblegum metal\\"?
B0009A1AS2|2.0|DT is a prog metal band. But i guess many fans focus more on \\"prog\\" than on \\"metal.\\" Though this album shows some metal sounds, where the hell is proggy sound? No creativity found. For the most of the songs, it's like once-you-hear-the-beginning-part-you-can-predict-the-rest. Like the other songs, Octavarium's 24 mins is completely wasted. They could use only 8 mins (ain't it more relevant to \\"Octavarium?\\")to express exactly same feelings. I think it's time to turn to different bands like Symphony X.
0143034901|4.0|THE SHADOW OF THE WIND was receommended by a friend who lives in Europe.  Although it was a New York Times Bestseller at some point, I must have missed it.  Since I visited Barcelona years ago and also am a lover of books I had great anticipation about this novel.  For the most part, the book was equal to my anticipation.<br /><br />At the center of the story is the young Daniel, the son of a Barcelona  book dealer and his serach for Julian Carax and his novels.  The first subplot introduces the reader to the blind Clara and her household, which Daniel quickly becomes a part of.  But this is the first of many subplots, perhaps too many.  Daniel's life becomes absorbed with the search for Julian and the reader becomes absorbed in the many subplots that reveal the tortured life of Julian Carax and the people who surround his life.<br /><br />It seemed to me that somewhere along the line the author forgot about Clara and at the end tells the reader what happens to her. Daniel's chance meeting with a homeless man and their ultimate friendship was pretty predictable. The author takes the reader through a labyrinth of characters that weave their way through the streets of Barcelona, some of which got almost too confusing.<br /><br />Somewhere around page 300 or so I kept getting the feeling \\"enough is enough.\\" I wondered how he was going to pull it all together at the end. Through many interlocking relationships, Ruiz Zafron brings the book to a close, but I felt that some of the endings were a little contrived.  But once you introduce a character you have to create an ending for them.  However, all in all I enjoyed the book.  For those who have been to Barcelona, there are many references to streets and locations.<br /><br />All in all, it's worth the read.

B00004RFFI|2.0|This film is a bit dated now, having come out almost ten years ago, but it still sports excellent special effects and, for its day, had amazing (and still amazing) CGI tornadoes.  However -- and this for me is a big however -- there's nothing else.  The plot is thinner than deli-sliced meat, the acting (Helen Hunt aside) is sophomoric, and the dialog would make a saint cringe.  Now, to err on the side of the actors, there wasn't much that could be done with the dialog -- it's like the Doublemint Twins wrote it.  Everything is repeated twice ... \\"Tornado at three o'clock!  Tornado at three o'clock!  I'm on it!  I'm on it!  Where's the road?  Where's the road?\\"  Stop the insanity, stop the insanity.  I can understand English quite well, especially when the actors are bellowing it out at 80 decibels. <br /> <br />Imagine \\"Speed\\" with worse dialog, but with more action and with less wooden acting than what Keanu Reeves delivers.  Now replace the bus with a red truck and the bomb with a series of tornadoes and you have \\"Twister\\".  I'll admit that I liked it when I saw it, the \\"wow\\" factor of the special effects being the draw for me, but now that I've seen it again I only notice the fast-slow-fast-slow pacing and the completely dreadful dialog.  This would make a decent rental for someone looking for mindless entertainment, but please don't buy it.
B0007P3582|2.0|50 Cent - The Massacre (G-Unit, 2005) <br /> <br />You love to hear the story. MC New Jack drops a great debut album but slips up on his second album. Yes, this is what's known as the sophomore jinx and it happens to a lot of your favorite rappers: Snoop, Nas, Jay-Z, Mos Def, Talib Kweli, Nappy Roots, Da Brat, etc. Well, you can add 50 Cent to the list with his weak follow-up to Get Rich or Die Tryin called The Massacre. <br /> <br />Don't get it twisted, though. It is far from a flop because it went platinum in the first week and will continue to sell based on 50's name alone. But this is one of those albums that you'll buy and ten years later you'll look back it saying either, \\"Man, I listened to THIS back then?\\" or \\"G-Unit/Shady/Aftermath was really falling off back then.\\" <br /> <br />The first problem are the beats. Since Fiddy doesn't stray from his usual subject matter (blasting guns, getting high, telling girls to \\"shake it\\", dissing others), he needs dope beats to hold the listener's attention. Dr. Dre's presence isn't felt as much as on his last album and although 50 doesn't need all Dre tracks to have a hot album, it sure wouldn't have hurt. Mediocre production plagues the album throughout, even with the well-known producers. Eminem slips with \\"Gatman and Robbin'\\" and Hi-Tek's bad luck continues with \\"Get in My Car\\". <br /> <br />The second problem are 50's lyrics which, as I said before, haven't changed much. They are all rehashed topics from his  first album. His diss track, \\"Piggy Bank\\", is aimed at Fat Joe and Jadakiss. Although this beef is old news now, I find it funny that 50 is mad that the two rappers guested on his foe Ja Rule's \\"New York\\" song, and that song wasn't even a hit. Oh well, it got people to buy this album. If you do a few fast-forwards, there are a couple of good songs like \\"Ski Mask Way\\" (the chorus is based off of a Biggie line from the \\"Flava In Ya Ear\\" remix), \\"A Baltimore Love Thing\\", the remix to The Game's \\"Hate It of Love It\\", and \\"I Don't Need 'Em\\". The latter uses the same marching band sample that Ghostface used for \\"Metal Lungies\\" last year but to 50's advantage, more people bought this album than Ghost's album so the beat might as well be new. <br /> <br />But that's it. There aren't many dope gangsta tracks to keep the thugs interested and the only singles released so far are for the ladies (\\"Disco Inferno\\", \\"Candy Shop\\", \\"Just a Lil' Bit\\"). And judging from Eminem's mediocre album, Game's overhyped album, and Lloyd Banks' and Young Buck's album sales not even totalling as much as what 50 sold, the G-Unit/Shady/Aftermath dynasty seems to be fading. If you haven't picked up this album yet, just listen to Get Rich or Die Tryin' instead. You'll get the same effect but with better production. -EJR
