On \\"Grace\\" Jeff Buckley opens the door to his soul and you will not be able to forget his voice ever again..he will expand in you and you will be hooked faster than you know. I'm not exaggerating, it's true - i know it by experience. You will want more after you heard this album, you'll always want more, believe me.
B0000C1733|4.0|Albeit that I already reviewed this CD once, I think it's important that I talk about this thing again on the account that sometime later this year the Red Hot Chili Peppers will release their ninth studio effort. <br /> <br />I read the reviews on here and I can tell most of them are the fans of the casual type. These are the people that got on to RHCP after albums like Calfornication and By The Way, when they turned away from their funk sound. True they became better musicians than when they were the trash metal, funked out, punk rockers with the hyper-energy, freakshow of the late 80s and early 90s, but the true fans of RHCP know that Blood Sugar Sex Magik (1991), Mother's Milk (1989), and The Uplift Mofo Party Plan (1987) are the definitive works of the Red Hot Chili Peppers and the reason why they are still around today for these \\"new\\" fans to enjoy. <br /> <br />The new fans have to understand something, funk has always been apart of the Red Hot Chili Peppers and they are actually going back to it (if you don't believe me listen to Fortune Faded, Save the Population on this collection and Rolling Sly Stone and the Black Cross (a cover) off of Live at Hyde Park), which might turn off the new fans. <br /> <br />Then again, the Red Hot Chili Peppers without funk is like American flag with no stars on it, it just doesn't sound right. <br /> <br />Anyways, on to the Greatest Hits collection. It is a Warner Bros. release, which has struck a nerve with many older RHCP fans since it did not include their material from their EMI heyday (although strangely Higher Ground made it on to here and that was from Mother's Milk, an EMI album). Nonetheless it really is not bad. <br /> <br />Four tracks from Blood Sugar Sex Magik - Under The Bridge, Give It Away, Breaking The Girl, and Suck My Kiss made the cut onto this collection. Suck My Kiss (best job Flea has ever done on bass) and Give It Away (Frusciante's guitar is pretty wicked) stay true to their \\"heritage\\" of sorts...rockin' while funkin' out at the same time. Breaking The Girl is like classical music with a heavy bass, and it's one of the better jobs that Anthony Kiedis has done on vocals and Under The Bridge is a rather impressive 4 1/2 minutes of work with the closing choir vocals and Flea's soothing bass. <br /> <br />A B-side to Blood Sugar Sex Magik, Soul To Squeeze which later appeared on the Coneheads soundtrack stands out as the best RHCP song ever done. It blew me away when I heard it. <br /> <br />Scar Tissue, Otherside, Californication, Parallel Universe, and Road Trippin all made it off the Peppers' 1999 release Californication. Strangely, it's only five of the six tracks that  made top 50 on the modern rock charts. The other one, the notably omitted Around The World was actually a modern rock number one so I'm baffled as to why that was left out. Nonetheless, to me, Parallel Universe is the best one to make it off of Californication and I don't know why that wasn't released as a single with one of the best guitar minute-long solos I have ever heard. <br /> <br />By The Way and Universally Speaking made here off of RHCP's last release, By The Way from 2002. Most American fans are confused as to why Universally Speaking is on here instead of Can't Stop or The Zephyr Song. Universally Speaking was actually released as a single overseas, but as much as I like Universally Speaking, Can't Stop would have been a much better fit. Plus, the CD is only 65-67 minutes long, so they could have added Zephyr Song also. <br /> <br />My Friends is the only track from One Hot Minute when they had Dave Navarro at guitar. Other people loved it, and true, it is rather beautiful, but it is usually a track I skip because it just dragged way too much. (I guess it comes from being between Breaking The Girl and Higher Ground). They should also added Aeroplane from One Hot Minute. Dave Navarro was a pretty good influence on the band...even though I really wasn't all too crazy about the fact that him and Anthony kissed in the video for Warped...which was actually sort of a dumb song anyway and at least that didn't make the cut. <br /> <br />Here's the real injustice. Higher Ground is the only song from the 80s to make it on to Greatest Hits. True, Higher Ground put them in the Top 20, but Knock Me Down and Taste The Pain all made Top 50 I think and at least one of them if not both should have made the cut on to the Greatest Hits CD since they did get permission to get Higher Ground from EMI. <br /> <br />The two new songs, Fortune Faded and Save The Population were taken from the recording session in August 2003 when they recorded 15 songs. They are pretty impresive and pretty funky...in a spacy out sort of way. <br /> <br />If you listen to this collection and you're a hardcore fan you are going to miss the old band even more. There's no rousing rockers like Fight Like A Brave and Me and My Friends, powerful ballads like Knock Me Down, hardcore funk like Taste The Pain, Hollywood, Behind The Sun, Jungle Man, Funky Monks, or The Power of Equality. Listening to this over and over as hardcore fan gives you a sense of nostalgia as you listen in hunger for the old band. <br /> <br />I hope that the newest album they come out with comes back with the familiar spark that they had from the first nine years of the band's existence.

Skills are necessary to avoid trial and error.  Identifying talents is important because a lot of action is instinctive. B00005JKTF|4.0|Charlotte Gray was something of a box-office disaster in the States, which damaged its reputation in the rest of the world. While it's not hard to see why American audiences didn't go for it, it's harder to understand the malice European critics greeted it with. It's a pretty good portrait of resistance infighting (the Communists are setup by the De Gaullists as liberation approaches), local collaboration (the schoolteacher gladly helps the Nazis root out Jewish families) and the nuts and bolts of resistance work. No great heroics or big setpieces, which is probably why it tanked: the big climax is more an emotional risk than the rescue audiences probably wanted. Performances are mostly good - Blanchett is much better than contemporary reviews would have you believe in particular. There are better films, but it's a good movie and for my money better than the alright Lucie Aubrac. I liked it enough to buy the DVD.  <br />

0452282152|5.0|Most people recognize Vermeer as the Dutch master who created priceless works of art.  Yet little else is known about him or the subjects that he chose to paint.  In this fictional tale author Tracy Chevalier brings to life that mysterious model for the Girl with the Pearl Earring.  It is through her eyes and voice that we learn about the enigmatic Vermeer and about 17th century Dutch culture.    This simple yet absorbing storyline flows seamlessly under Chevalier graceful penmanship. In this tautly written novel, Chevalier creates a cast of intriguing characters - the cold and stoic Vermeer, his emotionally fragile and volatile wife Catharina, the powerful matriarch Maria Thins, the lecherous patron van Ruijven and the modest yet radiant Griet.   It is through these characters that Chevalier creates the intriguing premise for how that Vermeer masterpiece came to be.  A thoroughly wonderful and highly recommended read.

B0009PVZWI|1.0|THE WHOLE POINT OF DUALDISC WAS TO OFFER A CD COMPATIBLE LAYER ON ONE SIDE AND A DVD AUDIO LAYER ON THE OTHER SIDE, BUT TO MAKE THINGS FAIR THE FOUNDERS OF THIS FORMAT AGREED THAT AT THE VERY LEAST, THE DVD LAYER HAD TO CONTAIN SOUND QUALITY \\"NOT INFERIOR TO THE CD LAYER\\", SO SONY BEING WHO THEY ARE DECIDED THEY WOULD SKIMP, THE REASON: SONY CREATED THE SACD FORMAT BASED ON THEIR DSD TECHNOLOGY, AND A YEAR LATER MERIDIAN LISCENSED OUT \\"MLP\\" (MERIDIAN LOSSLESS PACKING)THUS DVD AUDIO WAS BORN, NEITHER FORMAT EXPLODED, IN LARGE PART  BECAUSE OF LACK OF SUPPORT FROM THE STUDIOS, WELL SONY HAS UN-OFFICIALLY CLOSED THEIR SACD PLANT, AND DUALDISC WAS SUPPOSED TO CARRY ON THE DVD AUDIO FORMAT, BUT SONY WILL NOT PAY ROYALTIES TO A FORMAT THEY DIDNT CREATE, SO THEY OFFER \\"CHEAP\\" DOLBY DIGITAL 5.1 MIXES AND STEREO THAT IS IDENTICAL TO CD QUALITY ON THE DVD LAYER, UNIVERSAL HAS PROVEN THAT YOU CAN FIT DVD AUDIO AND DOLBY MIXES ON THE DVD LAYER AS WELL AS VIDEO CONTENT. THE REASON SONY CALLS IT \\"ENHANCED STEREO\\" IS FOR THE SIMPLE FACT THAT MOST DVD PLAYERS SOUND BETTER THAN THE CD PLAYERS THAT PEOPLE ARE USED TO (I.E. MULTI-DISC CHANGERS AND WALKMANS) BUT WHEN YOU PLAY A DUALDISC ON GOOD EQUIPMENT YOU CANT HERE A DIFFERENCE IN DISC SIDES, THIS IS FACT, NOT OPINION. SO THE ONE THING THAT THE AUDIO COMMUNITY SHOULD DO IS STOP BUYING DUALDISCS THAT MERELY STATE THAT THEY CONTAIN \\"ENHANCED ANYTHING\\" KETS KILL THIS FORMAT AND FORCE THE STUDIOS TO RELEASE HI RESOLUTION MUSIC THAT TRUE MUSIC LOVERS CAN ENJOY, NOT THESE FILE RIPPING, IPOD TOTING WHINERS THAT COMPLAIN WHEN THEY CANT ENJOY THE MUSIC THEY \\"PAID FOR\\" THE WAY THEY WANT. <br />SORRY TO SAY FOLKS,BUT DOWNLOADED MUSIC SOUNDS LIKE CRAP. <br /> <br />IM DONE, I HOPE EVERYONE READS THIS

0451196716|3.0|I couldn't put the book down, to be honest with you. The premise is just too interesting and there's never a dull moment. But ultimately the story really didn't amount to much.  <br /> <br />There's a very \\"Oh, the humanity!\\" theme running throughout the book as these teenage boys(who are strangely articulate and deeply profound for adolescents) walk themselves into madness and death. Meanwhile, spectators watch from the sidelines with signs, waving and smiling, cheering their favorite, treating the event like it were the olympics except for the collecting of feces and discarded shoes. Many times, I couldn't help but scratch my head and wonder: Why kill the guy who drops in cold blood? What's the point? If the contestants are there voluntarily, why should I sympathize? And why do so many people actually WANT to be in this thing?  <br /> <br />It would've helped if King would have described even vaguely the kind of world these boys inhabit that this kind of contest would exist, but he doesn't.   <br /> <br />So many questions are left unanswered by the end, which was anticlimactic at best. Quite frustrating.  <br /> <br />Also, some of the deaths seemed very unrealistic (one kid rips out his own throat), as well as the implausability of keeping at a constant 4mph pace for almost a week with no rest. That's very fast, almost running.  <br /> <br />It is, however, a very entertaining read. If you start it, you WILL finish it.

6301620208|5.0|European movie critics didn't like \\"The Day After.\\"  They said that it was not well made and was poorly acted.  They may have been right.  But that was not the point.  This movie is brave in that it only tries to do one thing.  That is to show what would happen if there were a nuclear war.  Therefore, it deserves to be ranked as one of the best made-for-TV movies of all times. <br /> <br />The setting is not New York or Los Angeles or any of the huge cities.  It is Kansas City and nearby Lawrence, Kansas, home of the University of Kansas.  The subplots of the characters lives are appropriately interrupted by the falling of the bombs. <br /> <br />The first scene after the nuclear explosions is outdoor rubble and falling snow.  But it's not snow.  It's fallout.  The doctor character played by Jason Robards is overwhelmed by those needing treatment at the humble campus hospital which is the only remaining hospital for perhaps 100 miles.  People stand in line for a sip of uncontaminated water from a pump.  All of these images are horrifying but they are based on scientific research.  <br /> <br />When this movie was first aired on TV in November 1983 experts warned that those less than 13 years old should not be exposed to this film.  But the movie was so highly publicized before its airing that no parent could possibly be unaware of the content of \\"The Day After\\" let alone that it was going to be on TV.  The night it was on, it became one of the 20 highest rated television programs of all time.  The next morning schools across the country had classroom discussions about this movie. <br /> <br />Since that time, Reagan and Gorbachev made massive reductions in nuclear arms.  The Soviet Union itself has disbanded.  The threat of a Cold War nuclear confrontation is now diminished.  But in some ways we are less safe.  The Soviet breakup left nuclear weapons scattered around several breakaway republics.  Russia brought those nukes home but their ability to keep these weapons secured from thieves is in doubt. <br /> <br />And based on what happened on 9/11/01, there are people who may be crazy enough to use them.  Now anti-Western sentiment comes not from Communist controlled Eastern republics but from radical Islamic Jihadists who we know are actively seeking nuclear weapons.  If these terrorists had the opportunity to use a nuclear weapon in an attack in the United States, it would make the World Trade Center attack look like a firecracker in comparison. <br /> <br />\\"The Day After\\" is realistic with the following caveat.  A caption at the end of the movie tells us that the effects of a nuclear war would actually be worse than depicted here. Over twenty years later, this movie unfortunately still has some relevance.  <br />

1932100385|5.0|Six years ago I was diagnosed with Crohn's disease (an inflammatory bowel disease).  I've always been a healthy eater and believe in natural healing whenever possible, especially through diet and (sigh!) stress reduction.  After my diagnosis, I cut out all sugar, wheat and ate even more vegetables and grains.  Although I hadn't consumed red meat in 20 years, I did still consume other animal protein.  While I was able to successfully control my crohn's disease this way, it was not until reading The China Study that I completely eliminated chicken, turkey, eggs, and cow's dairy.  I still eat a small amount of goat yogurt and goat cheese and some fish, and I've never felt better! <br /> <br />It was not The China Study alone that influenced my decision to drastically reduce my animal protein consumption.  While Dr. Campbell's results are compelling, worrying about contracting some disease in the future is not always enough to persuade most of us to stop eating hamburgers, chicken, eggs or ice cream.  The American diet revolves around these foods and it takes a concerted effort to find satisfying alternatives. <br /> <br />What cinched my decision to further reduce my animal protein consumption was the information I read in other books about the effect of factory farming on our health, environment, and our collective sense of humanity.  <br /> <br />Together with The China Study, these books make for impressive reading: <br />* Animal Liberation by Peter Singer <br />* The Food Revolution: How Your Diet Can Help Save Your Life and the World by John Robbins <br />* Plant Roots: Reasons Why the Human Diet is Rooted Exclusively in Plants by Rex Bowlby <br /> <br />When you consider that it takes 2,500 gallons of water to produce one pound of beef vs. approximately 24 gallons to produce one pound of wheat, something's wrong.  In addition, my consciousness was raised when I realized how animals in factory farms (where most animals we eat are raised) are treated and killed.I was beyond horrified.  All I know is that once my awareness was raised there was no going back. <br /> <br />Whether you choose to cut out animal protein completely or simply be more conscious in your decisions about what and when you eat it, The China Study along with these other books all give you food for thought.  I can't encourage people enough to read them and come to your own conclusions.

0380778556|5.0|After reading the book, \\"Rebecca\\", I can understand why it is mandatory reading for a high school English class. The writing and language of Daphne DuMaurier is exquisitely rich with such precision to detail, one can easily enter the stage she sets and the worlds she creates.<br /><br />The story is told through the eyes of a young woman whose name is never mentioned,  unless Mademoiselle, and later Madame and Mrs. DeWinter.  Beginning at the ending, in the first two chapters, the narrative begins again, in Monte Carlo as a hired companion to a boorish matronly social-climber, while befriending a widower on holiday who suddenly asks her hand in marriage before she is required, by duty, to leave Monte Carlo for New York.  The simple-bred and educated young woman henceforth lives within the aristocratic English estate, Manderley, and the shadow of Rebecca, the recently deceased former wife of her new husband where she finds superficial manners and politeness as well as drama and mystery.<br /><br />Here is one example of the part Rebecca plays in the story, from the new Mrs. DeWinter's point of view:  \\"I could fight the living but I could not fight the dead.  If there was some woman in London that Maxim loved, someone he wrote to, visited, dined with, slept with, I could fight with her.  We would stand on common ground.  I should not be afraid.  Anger and jealousy were things that could be conquered.  One day the woman would grow old or tired or different, and Maxim would not love her any more.  But Rebecca would never grow old.  Rebecca would always be the same.  And she and I could not fight.  She was too strong for me.\\"  (But wait until you find out how Rebecca died....)<br /><br />The sequel to this story, written by Susan Hill Long, is called \\"Mrs. DeWinter\\", so I'm assuming the narrator's given name still remains a mystery even there.

B000929AJQ|3.0|Six years since the massively creative and subconscious mind blowing release of The Fragile, Trent Reznor has released his latest...With Teeth. I cant seem to figure out what he's been working on for six years, because I doubt it was this album. <br />  <br />Before one gets the impression that this album is garbage, I need to say that there are some good songs on here, I really enjoyed them. Compared to the time and effort apparent in The Fragile though, I feel like Trent might have been too busy with gardening or something to really commit to this CD.  <br />The sound is much more simplified and natural than his previous releases, without the artistry and innovation that distinguished The Fragile and The Downward Spiral from similar music.  <br />The lyrics seem to be lacking the cohesiveness and genuine self examination of his other works. It seems like Trent is having difficulty getting lost in himself anymore, which would be alright if he could bring about his current emotions as masterfully as he did his anger and hopelessness, but its sounds more like hes trying to get in touch with a part of himself he doesnt relate to anymore. <br />I have to commend him on his vocal style though, it is still Reznor and its refreshing to hear his voice again. <br /> <br /> I would have enjoyed more studio work and synth effects on this album, to compliment Twiggy's recognizable bass, and to balance Grohls all too natural drumming. The depth lost by tossing most of the electronics for this album has created a sound that makes me a little uncomfortable and at times embarrased for Trent, because he seems a little naked.  <br /> <br />Yes, the White Stripes are doing well without any electronics, and Reznor seems to give a nod to that 80's rock sound with this album, but it seems like he's expiramenting with clothes that just dont fit him. I hope this isnt the end for NIN, but Im not going to hold my breath for another six years to find out.

If you read a lot you might hit a point where you are bemoaning the fact that you have read all of the good authors out there. And then you will pick up a book and unexpectedly set forth on a whole new landscape. Now when I look back at moments where I was finding difficulty in discovering new authors to plunder, I only wish that someone had pointed me in Pratchett's direction.<br /><br />This series is very much like the much more widely read `Hitchhikers Guide to the Galaxy'... only better. I was laughing out loud time and again as I flipped through these pages. And in the boundaries of this genre (humorous fantasy), I can't think of an author being able to top what lies before you if you have yet to read these books.<br /><br />The reason I did not give this book five stars lies in the fact that I don't think that `The Color of Magic' manages to pass muster against other authors whom leave more of a wake in their passage. George RR Martin is an author who has just completed the fourth in a series of fantasy novels that will just blow your mind away. They are not humorous. The heft of Martin's series emotionally and plot wise makes a small book like `Color of Magic' pale slightly in comparison. But that aside, this is a book that I would heartily recommend. Enjoy.

Unfortunately Prey doesn't! <br />It isn't that the premise lacks timeliness - nano-manufacturing is becoming a very realistic process. It may just be that I know very little about diseases and the cloning of DNA and a lot about micro-machines. Working in the area of software agents that \\"swarm\\" within computer networks and learn through group experience, we humans can make the \\"software\\" only so smart. Building micro, self powered, flying devices that can monitor air quality or send video feeds back to remote \\"observers\\" - not controllers - are moving out of laboratories and into field testing today. But, we are far, far away from the premise of Prey. <br />Crichton has moved from industrial fantasy to science fiction in Prey. Yes it is exciting - it is a good airplane read. But, it is not at the level of many of his other books. I await his next.
B00005AR3G|5.0|Ever since people have been going to the movies there has been one constant in the realm of cartoon movies, Disney Studios.  Disney has created unforgettable classics; such as, \\"The Lion King\\", \\"Aladdin\\", \\"Snow White\\", \\"Bambi\\", and the list could go on and on.  During the mid-nineties, the \\"House of Mouse\\" as Disney Studios is often referred to as, changed animation styles and began delivering audiences clunkier drawn characters that didn't seem to have the distinct visual style and grace that made their films instant classics with children and adults alike.  However, there were some gems amongst the average animation being created, and one of these gems that would soon join all of the other Disney classics was, \\"The Emperor's New Groove\\". <br /> <br />\\"The Emperor's New Groove\\" is about a young, self-involved emperor named Kuzco (perfectly cast David Spade), who cares little for other people and only desires to make himself happy.  Under his employ is the incredibly old and insanely evil, Yzma (Eartha Kitt) and her unwitting sidekick Kronk (the hilarious Patrick Warburton).  Yzma desires to rule the kingdom but her dreams are thwarted when Kuzco catches her trying to settle disputes by using his power and has her fired.  This doesn't set well at all with Yzma, who along with Kronk, devises a plan to kill the emperor.  In Kronk's defense, he really has no clue what's going on, and is really a good man at heart.  However, Yzma's plan quickly goes awry when Kronk accidentally chooses the wrong potion and instead of killing Kuzco, it turns him into a llama.  In the middle of all of this insanity is Pacha (John Goodman), a simple villager who was summoned by Kuzco only to learn that the young emperor is going to destroy his village in order to create Kuzcotopia.  Of course, since the emperor is in the form of a llama, and has mistakenly been taken back to Pacha's village it's up to Pacha to convince Kuzco to change his mind and open his heart, while evading Yzma's evilclutches. <br /> <br />This hilarious cartoon, probably one of the funniest Disney has made in years, has plenty of jokes and sight gags to keep both young and old rolling with laughter for the entire duration of the film and even long after the movie is over.  With a convoluted plot that is intended to be pure fun, even poking fun at it's own absurdity, \\"The Emperor's New Groove\\" is the perfect film for people of all ages. <br /> <br />\\"The Emperor's New Groove\\" is rated G.

Mariah is on fire. Its seems as if she has finally found her niche. First she was labled an adult contemporary singer, then a pop singer, now Mariah has made the full transistion to R&B singer. Welcome to the club girlfriend!    With guest appearances from Jermaine Dupree(JD), Snoop, Twista and Nelly, this album has a range of club hits and slow ballads, with a little bit of something for everyone. She still has those high ocatane vocals that would make Whitney Houston, Rachelle Farrell and even opera singer Denece Graves green with envy.    the lead single, the JD produced hit Its Like that, has been bumping in the clubs and on radio since January of this year..with background vocals from hitmaker Fat Man Scoop, this single got plenty of play on radio stations around the country.    The second single, We Belong Together, ended up being Mariah's 16th number one single, the most ever by a female artist and only one number one hit away from tying Elvis Presley for the most ever by a solo artist. We Belong together, who I think was \\"dedicated\\" to Derek Jeter on the cool, was Mariah's call for that special man to come back...this song has been a hit on radio stations everywhere. I play I wish you knew over and over..I absolutely love that jam!!!    Fly like a bird, which takes a gospel approach, is an outstanding song as well.     Mariah keeps these songs short and to the point, as the whole entire cd is only 50 minutes long, but she put in a bunch of work, believe that.      The beats to some of the songs are outstanding and overall, I think this is her best album in years, possibly since her debut album, or at least since the Daydream album in 1995...
0767803434|5.0|I was completely glued to my seat from beginning to end: this film was nonstop action, suspense and drama. While admittedly *today* in real life there would be intense security to prevent this from happening, it seems a highly plausible plot for a film, especially in 1997 when it was made. The world sat in disbelief when it was announced at a TV  press conference that Kazakhstan terrorists hold the U.S. President James Marshall, delegates, and various family members as hostages up on Air Force One not long after boarding the plane in Russsia. Communications between Glenn Close, the U.S. Vice President, a prisoner on Air Force One and the U.S. Press Secretary in Washington confirmed their status ...<br /><br />Harrison Ford plays the U.S. President with fearlessness and cunning. He also demonstrates superb hand-to-hand fighting skills plus superior technical expertise with a gun. He becomes the hero who manages to elude the terrorists when he remains one level below, as they overtake the pilot and copilot. He creates diversions and thwarts their various plans, all the while evading detection. Initially, they are unaware whom they are fighting. Once Ivan Korshunov, the leader, realizes it is the President of the United States who nearly single-handedly prevents them from achieving their goals, the terrorist becomes more vicious. He threatens the wife of the President at gun point and turns on the loudspeaker so the President can listen as she voices her fears. This enrages the President who takes even more serious measures to save their lives: he dumps fuel to force them to stop. The fighting scenes are unparalleled yet eventually Harrison Ford is captured. The capture of the President forces the United States to negotiate with the terrorists, despite their policy against doing so. The terrorists want the release of General Alexander Radek, the former ruler of Kazakhstan ...<br /><br />The rescue of the President, delegates and their families is breath-taking. Fortunately, some manage to jump with parachutes but there are not enough and time is running out ... Air Force One does not have the ability to land. There is a daring awe-inspiring rescue up in the air at 15,000 feet. General Alexander Radek is released from his prison cell, dressed in his well-decorated uniform as he walks across the prison courtyard ... and in the end, justice prevails. Viewing this film sends chills up and down one's spine because despite the many aspects of the film that are exaggerated - terrorism is one area that *thankfully* is *not* depicted in its true scope given what we know of the events of 9-1-1 and current Iraqi War. B000001Y5J|5.0|I'm sure you've heard the story behind this album, but I'll tell it again anyway. Pretty Hate Machine became a surprise hit. While it never broke into the top fourty it stayed in the top 100 for over a year, which is quite a feat. TVT felt that if they had more control over the music Trent recorded, than they could have an even bigger hit. Obviously Trent was not happy with this. This album was recorded secretly and is basically his \\"f**k you\\" to TVT. This is easily his angriest album, but if you can look past the angst you'll find a great mini-album.    This is not only his angriest album, but also the only one that would really fall into a Metal category. You can tell that Trent had been listening to a lot of Ministry around this time, because it sounds pretty much like their heavier albums with better singing. That's not to say that it's a total rip-off, though. These songs are a lot catchier than Ministry was in their industrial-metal prime, and have a more melodic feel to them. There are also no political messages or samples, which were, and still are, a big part of Ministry.    The album opens with Pinion, a short instrumental that repeats the same 6 chords over and over. It begins almost silent with something that sounds like the wind in the background, but as the song goes on it gets louder and louder until it finally becomes undistorted. 3/5    Immediately after the last few chords of Pinion, Wish begins with a very memorable drum beat. This is probably the most well known song on the album. It has an interesting music video, and it won a Grammy for best Heavy Metal song of 1993. It's easy to see why. It follows Trent's signature loud-soft-loud plan, and it's as good as any of his heavier songs. 5/5    Next is my personal favorite song on the album, Last. A lot of people find the lyrics to be cheesy, and I will say that he goes a bit over the top here. But the music is incredible. It's very rare that a song can be both this catchy and still retain all of its heaviness, but this songs suceeds. It also contains probably the best solos I've heard in an NIN song to date. 5/5    After Last is Help Me I Am In Hell, which is a short, soft instrumental break before the chaos of the next track. It's almost acoustic, and it keeps the album from becoming monotous. 4/5    The album's fifth track is the very noisy Hapiness in Slavery, the other single from the album. The video for this song featured performance artist Bob Flanigan being tortured to death. Of course this wasn't real, but the video was quickly banned from MTV after one airing, which usually gets more publicity for a song than being in rotation anyway. This is probably the only thing to hint at the Downward Spiral, but it still doesn't feel out of place. 5/5    The actual album finishes with Gave Up. Like Wish, it opens with a memorable drum beat, and is probably the most straightforward rock track on the album. However, it's also one of those songs that sounds a lot better live than in the studio. The version found on And All That Could've Been is much better. This version is still nice, though. 5/5    Depending on your copy of the album, the next track will be Physical, the album is over, or there are many tracks of silence following Gave Up. You should still have the last two tracks in some form, though.    The first of the two bonus tracks is Physical, which is a good cover of Adam Ant. If you listen closely you will hear Trent's dog barking in the background, and Trent will say \\"Eat your heart out Stevie\\", referring to his situation with TVT. This is a great track quite unlike anything Trent has done. It's also probably his raunchiest one, even more so than Closer. 5/5    The second of the two tracks is Suck, which has seen many versions, including various demos. While Trent was involved with the first released version by Pigface, this one is a lot different. That version was just Trent's vocals, Drums, and Bass, but Trent has fleshed it out with guitars on thechorus and a catchier bass line. He also added a bridge to the song. The opinion seems fairly unanimous that this version is better. Even Pigface plays it Trent's way. This also seems to be one of Trent's favorite songs to play live. The version on And All That Could Have Been is a bit heavier, but I think they're equally good. 5/5    If you're more into metal than alternative rock, than this is the NIN album for you. Even if you're not really a metal fan, you should still check it out, because it's a lot more interesting than some metal, and obviously it's more than just straightforward metal. It's the best EP Trent ever released and it's a very important chapter in the history of Nine Inch Nails. If you had any previous interest in NIN and don't own this, then you shouldn't hesitate. You won't be let down.
B00005QDW5|5.0|Echoes is one of the better greatest hits collections for any band out there. All the tracks on the album are truly definitive, showcasing the band's innovative and unique style throughout their existence. However, although the greatest hits are very complete, and good for a new fan of Pink Floyd, the band's strengths lie in the album approach. An album by Pink Floyd wasn't just 5 or 10 songs, it was a unit. Sure, you particularly enjoyed the individual songs on the album, but you got the music and understood it when the album was played as a whole. For example, this package includes Sheep from the Animals album. It's a good song, but we realize the true meaning of it when we listen to it with Pigs, Dogs, and Pigs on the Wing. But, if you want to get acquainted with the band, get this set. Afterwards, though, buy their albums, and understand the true meanings of the songs as part of the epic albums of the band.
B000002H33|5.0|I can't believe what you guys are saying about Metallica. \\"Metallica were goths in the '80s\\", \\"Metallica became better players on the Black album\\", \\"Nothing compared to St. Anger\\". Those are some of the stupidist things I've heard. And worst of all, the person who praised the Black album, also said the first five Metallica albums are crap, when that album was in fact the fifth album by the band. I think that shows just how ignorant these guys are. I'd also like to see what you guys think of progressive rock if 8 minutes is way too long. You people must not have a very long attention span.    Anyway, despite what those idiots down there think, I think this is easily Metallica's best album. Every song on here is memorable, and they all have a great message behind them, except for Orion which is an instrumental. There isn't a ton of variety on this album. It's all pretty much the loud thrash that came to define Metallica's style in the '80s, but that's certainly not a bad thing when the songs are this well written. Each song is fairly complex, yet simple enough to follow, and few Metallica songs, if any, require more technical skill than these. There is also a lot of variety in the lyrics. Hetfield deals with a variety of real issues on this album and each song is well thought out. Oh and I'd like to take a moment to compliment the album's art, which is some of the best I've seen.    The album opens with the classic acoustic intro to Battery. Then it gets heavier, but still very majestic, and then all hell breaks loose. The thrashiest track on the album. The lyrics are about a totalitarian government, perhaps the Nazis, that destroys and converts anything in their path. Metallica didn't have singles in those days, but I've heard this song get some radio play. 5/5    Next is the even more classic title track. This is probably the best track on the album, and also the longest one. It's mostly thrash, but there's also a great soft, melodic break in the middle. The lyricsare about a person being controlled by a drug, and for most of the song it is from the point of view of the drug. This has recieved a lot of radio play, and I'd say that is very justified. 5/5    The Thing that Should Not Be is another classic song by the band, but then again all of these tracks are classics. This is another one with a soft intro, but once again it's one of the album's heaviest tracks. It also features one of the best solos on the album. The lyrics are based off of a literature of the same name, and it's about a metaphorical monster of some sort. 5/5    Next is Welcome Home(Sanitarium), which is a mostly soft song, other than chorus and a bridge, which are much heavier. It also features more great solos. The lyrics are about a person who has been labeled insane and is afraid to leave their asylum but longs to anyway. 5/5    After that is Disposable Heroes. Appropriately, it begins very militant sounding, but eventually becomes thrasy, another one of the album's heaviest tracks. The lyrics are about a man who is sent to be in a corrupt war, where the soldiers are considered to be expendable. 5/5    Leper Messiah is the album's 6th track. Musically it's more of what you've heard on the album only a little slower, but that's certainly not a bad thing. Lyrically, it's about the corruption of religion in the past, specifically the Catholic Church. 5/5    Orion is the album's epic instrumental track. This is eight minutes of some of the most melodic metal I've ever heard. Probably my favorite track on the album. It's just surreal. You have to hear it for yourself to understand what I mean. 5/5    The album closes on a somewhat weaker note in Damage, Inc. It's easily my least favorite song on the album, and it's the most straightforward song on the album. Though, the intro is nice. The lyrics are also a little worse than the rest. Hetfield finally resorts to swearing to get his point across, and it talks vaguely about the conformity of society, which I guess is Damage, Inc. Still an incredible track despite being the weakest. 5/5    After this album Metallica released ...And Justice For All, which was good, but too complex for it's own good. After that they decided to go in the opposite direction on the self-titled, \\"Black Album\\", and it paid off for them, and it was still a good album. I think the lyrics lacked the intelligence of this album and Justice, and the music was much less complex, but it was still a good album. After that, though, things weren't even remotely Metallica-like. Load and Reload left behind anything remotely complex, and unfortunately marked the end of anything worthwhile coming from the band.    If you're only going to get just one Metallica album than this is definitely the one to get. Every song is great, and the lyrics should make you think.
B00002Z88D|5.0|This album is the best album I've ever heard in my life, and in my humble opinion, the best live album ever. The concept is so original, and even though it doesn't look good on paper -combining metal and hard rock with a symphony orchestra - it sounds amazing. Michael Kamen's [R.I.P.]arrangements for the symphony are spectacular. The way the symphony marries up with the band is absolutely phenomenal. I could listen to this album over and over every day for the rest of my life and not get bored. For the love of all that is holy, if you don't own this album, buy it right NOW! You'll thank me.

B000005IU2|5.0|The Stooges' second album is a brutal masterpiece. It is something that is neither pretty nor wholesome, and it succeeds almost entirely on the powerful chemistry at work on this album. Iggy screams, shouts, yelps, and grunts over a barrage of simplistic music with simplistic lyrics and, at times, no music at all (\\"L.A. Blues\\"). \\"Dirt\\" is my particular favorite, though, a slow, menacing song that manages to sound like nothing else on the album and still become its centerpiece. Other great tunes present here are \\"Down on the Street,\\" the excellent opener, \\"1970,\\" a perfect proto-punk anthem, and the title track, simply one of the finest, rawest, most visceral songs ever recorded. This album was one of the building blocks of the first wave of punk rock, inspiring people in the same way that the MC5 and the New York Dolls did. I love this album, and believe me, everyone should give it a listen. From the moment the electrifying \\"Down on the Street\\" begins all the way until the completely free-form jam \\"L.A. Blues\\" closes, Fun House grips the listener and allows no room for escape. And honestly, who would want to?    In conclusion, I will say this: everyone hates you, Howard Tuttleman. While this may gain me some unhelpful votes, your senseless review is matched only by your undoubtedly terrible taste in music. And to think, you really believe you have fans! Dare I ask what you like to listen to? Oh, and by the way, was it that hard to turn over the record? I mean, you turn it over, you set the needle down, and you listen. It takes all of ten seconds to do.

0375703764|4.0|Other authors use similar post-modern techniques; others mess with your mind and your definition of reality.  The strength of House of Leaves is that is does so in a funky, accessible manner.  True, the official story, that of a documentary on a house with (literally) a life of its own is more enjoyable if one recognizes its pseudo-academic nature.  True, the narrator's story in the footnotes is more enjoyable in the context of the beat and funk \\"biographies\\" that proceed it.  But anyone with an interest in horror-suspense or in experimental literature, can enjoy this literary romp in horror.  It is an imperfect but excellent introduction that can lead the reader into some of the masters (Edmund Jabes, Peter Esterhazy ...).

B00004W52U|5.0|When the right people come together at the right time in any context, wonderful things can be achieved. Operation Ivy's first and last album, Energy is an example of this. Jesse Michaels, Matt McCall, Lint and Dave Mello's only album as a band is one of the purest, most passionate(this will come up throughout this review) displays of youthful anger, rebellion and energy(so will this) I have ever heard. Sorry for the long song by song review, but I felt like doing it. Skip to the last paragraph if you want.  <br /> <br />Knowledge: The perfect album opener: It's short, sweet and ferocious. Jesse Michaels proudly exclaims \\"All I Know is that I Don't Know nothing\\" in this invigorating display of youthful exuberance and angst. No wonder it's one of the most covered punk rock songs of all time. 9.5/10 <br /> <br />Sound System: This song is crazy. With a memorable(though IMO kinda annoying) chorus and fluid, great verses. The band just oozes a ska vibe here. Bouncy, catchy and uplifting. 8.5/10 <br /> <br />Jaded: Jaded is a raging punk rocker with positive, intelligent lyrics. The chorus is catchy like a virus and the verses are pretty melodic. 9.5/10 <br /> <br />Take Warning: Op Ivy back off from the punk rock for a moment to bring Take Warning, a mid tempo reggaeish ska track. A catchy anthem against violence and intimidation in the punk scene. 9/10 <br /> <br />The Crowd: The Crowd is an attack on conformity and herd mentality. It's musically/structurally in the vein of Jaded. But it's even catchier, more energetic and better. 10/10 <br /> <br />Bombshell: Short, fast and furious. Quite a bombshell of a track. Not the best track, but it packs quite a wallop.    <br />8.5/10 <br /> <br />Unity: Op Ivy's famous call for peace and understanding between punks. Falls somewhere in between Take Warning and the next track Vulnerability. Another song that's catchy as hell with a great message to boot. The unified band chant at the end of song is a highlight. 10/10 <br /> <br/>Vulnerability: IMO, this is criminally underrated. You can hear the passion dripping from Jesse Michaels every word. A warning against the indifference that is so prevalent in our society. The rapid rhythmic changes at the end of the song are great. 10/10 <br /> <br />Bankshot: Great Ska instrumental! If you ever wanted to know what ska music is about, check this out. 9/10 <br /> <br />One of These Days: Cool rendition of a traditiona song. Better than Nancy Sinatra's version for sure.  <br />8.5/10 <br /> <br />Gonna Find You: Gonna Find You is another rip roaring punk rocker dealing with authority in general but particularly in education. 9/10 <br /> <br />Bad Town: Bad Town is another song about the punk scene with some cool horn lines. The best part of the song is near the end when the horns and guitars play a series of great lines. Interesting, but not one of the best. Plus, Jesse Michaels seldom fails to sing the chorus out of tune. But it's all good. 8.5/10 <br /> <br />Smiling: Another good but not amazing song. The pounding snare really sets the tone for the song and the chorus. ______does a good job here. 8/10 <br /> <br />Caution: Back to the really good stuff. This is another punk rocker with a memorable chorus. Invigorating and energetic. C-A-U-T-I-O-N 9.5/10 <br /> <br />Freeze Up: A political punk rocker with good lyrics and another great chorus. The hip hopish part here is really cool as well. Great bass work from Matt McCall. 9.5/10 <br /> <br />Artificial Life: An angry semi skaish rant against the shallow commericialism of our society. Another really good song. 9/10 <br /> <br />Room Without a Window: Room Without a Window is a political rocker that stretches Op Ivy's vocab a bit. It also forgoes typical song structure. The chorus isn't great but it's no big deal. 9.5/10 <br /> <br />Big City: More punk rock with intelligent lyrics, Lint's clean to fuzzed out guitar tone and a catchy chorus. The lyrics are of particular note. Some cool extendedmetaphors. 9/10 <br /> <br />Missionary: The only real anti religion song here. More pure punk anger. The lyrics are passionate and articulate their point well. 8.5/10 <br /> <br />Junkie's Running Dry: This song is an all out punk rock indictment of those who forgoe their beliefs to join the rat race. Uncompromising, raw and awesome. 9/10 <br /> <br />Here We Go Again: This isn't one of the best songs here, but I listen to it quite a bit. It has one of the best(and fun to play) basslines on the album. I've failed to give Matt McCall his due thus far, but he is one of the best punk bassists I've heard. He consistently churns out throbbing basslines on every track here. For his best work, I would have to point to Maxwell Murder by Rancid. 9/10 <br /> <br />Hoboken: Not a standout, but its more of punk rock ferocity that makes this album great. 8/10 <br /> <br />Yellin In My Ear: Yellin In My Ear is one catchy ska anthem. Who can't help singing/shouting along to the chorus once in a while. The production isn't the best(some of the shout outs are obscured) here but it can be forgiven. 9/10 <br /> <br />Sleep Long, Sleep Well: Another great chorus and lyrics about our society make this one more great song on this album. Jesse Michaels are particularly passionate on the verses here. 9/10 <br /> <br />Healthy Body, Sick Mind: An interesting attack on our health and competition crazy society that Op Ivy feel is so fundamentally flawed. Cool song and lyrical theme. 8.75/10 <br /> <br />Officer: More rebellious punk rock dealing with the perceived abuse of power by police officers. Not a really good song, but again, there is no real crap here. 8/10 <br /> <br />I Got No: Op Ivy made sure this album ended on a high note. Energy ends the same way it started, a concise, yet exciting punk rock song. 9.5/10 <br /> <br />Many band have tried to emulate the verve, intensity and creativity of Operation Ivy, but none have come close. If you are asking yourself whether to buy Energy,I would heed the advice of Operation Ivy and Pick it Up, Pick it Up!.

B0000CDLA7|4.0|Train of Thought. Dream Theater shows off their metal side on this record, opinions be damned. A lot of people did not lke this record because if it's heaviness.  <br /> <br />I thought this disc was great. But, then again, I was attracted to Dream Theater because of their metal side, anyway. The album artwork is in black and white, which reflects the music within. if you approach this disc with an open mind, you will be rewarded.  <br /> <br />As I Am - I think it was appropriate that they lead off an album like this with a song like this. This song blatently tells all naysayers that \\"We will do what we want, write the music we want, and say what we want, whether you like it or not\\"  <br /> <br />This Dying Soul - The continuation of the Mike Portnoy-penned lamentation on alcohol abuse. If you look in the liner notes to this song, you will see a small caption that says \\"To Bill W. and all his friends\\". Bill W. is the founder of Alcoholics Anonymous, and this song deals with steps 4 and 5 in the 12 steps to recovery. (The Glass Prison on 6DOIT is about steps 1-3, The Root of All Evil on Octavarium is about 6-8) There is also some great axemanship from John Petrucci.  <br /> <br />Endless Sacrifice - One of the more pleasant sounding songs on this record. This song deals with depression, and about how love can heal suffering. More great guitar work from Petrucci here.  <br /> <br />Honor Thy Father - This song is a sticking point for me whenever I hear it. On the positive side, there s some awesome riffing from John Petrucci here, and the lyrics are well thought out. On the negative side, the instrumental section at points gets on your nerves after a while. This song is why I deducted 1 star.  <br /> <br />Vacant - A melodic break from the rest of the record, and a refresher from the instrumental bit in Honor Thy Father. There is no guitar on this song, all you can hear is a cello sample, grand piano, and a digital pad effect from Jordan Rudess, John Myung's bass guitar, and emotive lyrics from James LaBrie. <br />  <br />Stream Of Conciousness - an 11 minute instrumental song. John Petrucci, Mike Portnoy, Jordan Rudess, and John Myung TASTEFULLY show off their chops here. It also has a very classical sound to it, too, which I like. Definitely the centerpiece of ths record.  <br /> <br />In The Name of God - Once again, John Petrucci shows that he is not only a master of the guitar, but master of the pen, too. This is a song about how certain people use religion to justify violence and inhumanity. It is the most chilling at about the 5 minute mark when James LaBrie refers to the Heaven's Gate, (Hundreds of believers lured into a doomsday cult), David Koresh and the branch Davidians (Self-Proclaimed messiah leading servants to their death) and Revrend Jim Jones and Jonestown (40 sons and daughters Unconsenting plural wives, perversions In the name of God). The song ends with a question that is very thought provoking (Does following faith lead us to violence?) <br /> <br />Yes, for the most part, this album is very heavy. But if you look beneath the metallic surface, you will find the intelligent and thought-provoking music that makes Dream Theater great.  <br />
